subtitle: both ends have membranes.

title: Indirectly Struck Membranophone
subtitle: membrane is set in vibration by indirect means, such as shaking.

title: Shaken Membranophone
subtitle: membrane is vibrated by objects inside the drum (rattle drums).

title: Plucked Membranophone
subtitle: membrane is set in vibration by plucking a string attached to it.

title: Plucked Drum
subtitle: string is plucked, causing the membrane to vibrate.

title: Friction Membranophone
subtitle: membrane is set in vibration by friction.

title: Friction Drum with Stick
subtitle: membrane is vibrated from a stick that is rubbed or used to rub the membrane.

title: Stick Inserted in Membrane
subtitle: stick is inserted in a hole in the membrane.

title: Stick Cannot Be Moved
subtitle: stick is fixed and rubbed.

title: Stick is Semi-Movable
subtitle: stick can be moved and rubbed.

title: Stick is Freely Movable
subtitle: stick is freely moved and rubbed.

title: Stick Tied Upright to Membrane
subtitle: stick is tied upright to the membrane.

title: Friction Drum with Cord
subtitle: cord attached to the membrane is rubbed.

title: Drum Held Stationary
subtitle: drum is held while playing.

title: Only One Usable Membrane
subtitle: only one end has a membrane.

title: Two Usable Membranes
subtitle: both ends have membranes.

title: Drum Twirled by Cord
subtitle: drum is twirled by a cord, which rubs in a notch on the stick held by the player.

title: Hand Friction Drum
subtitle: membrane is rubbed by hand.

title: Singing Membrane (Kazoo)
subtitle: membrane modifies other sounds by vibrating.

title: Free Kazoo
subtitle: membrane is vibrated by an unbroken column of wind, without a chamber.

title: Tube or Vessel Kazoo
subtitle: membrane is placed in a box, tube, or other container.

title: Unclassified Membranophone
subtitle: membranophone that does not fit into the above categories.

title: Chordophone
subtitle: instrument that produces sound primarily by means of vibrating strings stretched between fixed points.

title: Simple Chordophone or Zither
subtitle: instrument consisting of strings and a string bearer, with or without a resonator box.

title: Bar Zither
subtitle: string bearer is bar-shaped.

title: Musical Bow
subtitle: flexible bar zither, often curved.

title: Idiochord Musical Bow
subtitle: string is cut from the bark of the cane, remaining attached at each end.

title: Mono-Idiochord Musical Bow
subtitle: one string only.

title: Poly-Idiochord Musical Bow or Harp-Bow
subtitle: several strings.

title: Heterochord Musical Bow
subtitle: string is of separate material from the bearer.

title: Mono-Heterochord Musical Bow
subtitle: one heterochord string only.

title: Poly-Heterochord Musical Bow
subtitle: several heterochord strings.

title: Stick Zither
subtitle: rigid string carrier.

title: Musical Bow/Stick
subtitle: one rigid and one flexible end.

title: True Stick Zither
subtitle: round sticks, not hollow, used as string carrier.

title: Tube Zither
subtitle: string bearer is a tube.

title: Whole Tube Zither
subtitle: string carrier is a complete tube.

title: Idiochord Tube Zither
subtitle: string is cut from the tube.

title: Heterochord Tube Zither
subtitle: string is separate from the tube.

title: Half-Tube Zither
subtitle: strings stretched along the convex surface of a gutter.

title: Raft Zither
subtitle: string bearer is composed of canes tied together in the manner of a raft.

title: Board Zither
subtitle: string bearer is a board.

title: With Resonator Box
subtitle: includes piano.

title: Trough Zither
subtitle: strings are stretched across the mouth of a trough.

title: Frame Zither
subtitle: strings are stretched across an open frame.

title: Composite Chordophone
subtitle: instrument with a resonator as an integral part, including lutes, harps, and similar.

title: Lute

title: Bow Lute
subtitle: each string has its own flexible carrier.

title: Yoke Lute or Lyre
subtitle: strings attached to a yoke in the same plane as the sound-table.

title: Handle Lute
subtitle: string bearer is a plain handle.

title: Necked Bowl Lute
subtitle: e.g., mandolin, balalaika.

title: Necked Box Lute
subtitle: e.g., guitar, violin.

subtitle: no pillar.

subtitle: has a pillar.

All Strings in One Plane
subtitle: inline chromatic harp.

subtitle: cross-strung harp.

title: Aerophone
subtitle: instrument that produces sound primarily by means of vibrating air, without the vibration of strings or membranes.

title: Free Aerophone
subtitle: instrument in which the vibrating air is not contained within the instrument.

title: Displacement Free Aerophone
subtitle: air is set in motion by a sharp edge or moving object (e.g., bullroarer).

title: Interruptive Free Aerophone
subtitle: air stream is periodically interrupted (e.g., siren, harmonica).

title: Idiophonic Interruptive Aerophone or Reed
subtitle: air stream is directed against a lamella, setting it in periodic vibration.

title: Concussion Reed
subtitle: two lamellae make a gap which closes periodically during their vibration.

title: Percussion Reed
subtitle: a single lamella strikes against a frame.

title: Free-Reed Instrument
subtitle: reed vibrates within a closely fitting slot (e.g., accordion, harmonica).

title: Band Reed Instrument
subtitle: air hits the sharp edge of a band under tension.

title: Non-Idiophonic Interruptive Instrument
subtitle: interruptive agent is not a reed.

title: Rotating Aerophone
subtitle: interruptive agent rotates in its own plane (e.g., siren disk).

title: Whirling Aerophone
subtitle: interruptive agent turns on its axis (e.g., bullroarer, whirly tube).

title: Plosive Aerophone
subtitle: sound is caused by a single compression and release of air (e.g., udu).

title: Mixed Sets of Free Aerophones
subtitle: sets of free aerophones of different types.

title: Non-Free Aerophone (Wind Instrument Proper)
subtitle: instrument in which the vibrating air is contained within the instrument.

title: Edge-Blown Aerophone (Flute)
subtitle: air is directed against an edge.

title: Flute Without Duct
subtitle: player creates a ribbon-shaped stream of air with their lips.

title: End-Blown Flute
subtitle: player blows against the sharp rim at the upper open end of a tube.

title: Side-Blown Flute
subtitle: player blows against the sharp rim of a hole in the side of the tube.

title: Vessel Flute
subtitle: body of the pipe is vessel-shaped.

title: Flute With Duct (Duct Flute)
subtitle: a narrow duct directs the air-stream against the sharp edge of a lateral orifice.

title: Flute With External Duct
subtitle: duct is outside the wall of the flute.

title: Flute With Internal Duct
subtitle: duct is inside the tube.

title: Vessel Flute With Duct
subtitle: vessel-shaped body with duct.

title: Reed Aerophone
subtitle: air vibrates a reed.

title: Double Reed Instrument
subtitle: two lamellae beat against one another (e.g., oboe, bassoon).

title: Single Reed Instrument
subtitle: pipe has a single reed (e.g., clarinet, saxophone).

title: Reedpipe With Free Reed
subtitle: reed vibrates through a closely fitted frame, with fingerholes (e.g., bawu, hulusi).

title: Reedpipe With Band Reed
subtitle: band reed in a pipe.

title: Non-Idiophonic Interruptor Pipe
subtitle: interruptive agent is not a reed.

title: Rotating Aerophone Pipe
subtitle: disk rotates in its own plane.

title: Whirling Aerophone Pipe
subtitle: tube turns on its axis.

title: Trumpet Aerophone
subtitle: air is set in motion by the player's lips.

title: Natural Trumpet
subtitle: no means of changing pitch except by player's lips (e.g., bugle, didgeridoo).

title: Conch

title: Tubular Trumpet
subtitle: tube is straight or curved.

title: Chromatic Trumpet
subtitle: pitch can be altered mechanically.

title: Keyed Trumpet
subtitle: pitch changed by keys (e.g., ophicleide).

title: Slide Trumpet
subtitle: pitch changed by slide (e.g., trombone).

title: Valved Trumpet
subtitle: pitch changed by valves (e.g., trumpet, tuba).

title: Mixed Sets of Wind Instruments
subtitle: sets of wind instruments of different types.

title: Mixed Sets of Aerophones
subtitle: sets of aerophones of different types played together.

title: Electrophone
subtitle: instrument that produces or modifies sound primarily by electrical means.

title: Electrically Actuated Acoustic Instrument
subtitle: acoustic instrument where sound is produced by traditional means but actuated electrically (e.g., pipe organ with electric action).

title: Electrically Amplified Acoustic Instrument
subtitle: acoustic instrument whose sound is amplified electrically (e.g., electric guitar, electric violin).

title: Electrical Oscillation Instrument
subtitle: instrument where sound is produced by electrical oscillators (e.g., theremin, synthesizer).

title: Machine
subtitle: device using power to perform tasks.

title: Building
subtitle: structure with walls and a roof.

title: Vehicle
subtitle: device used for transport.

title: Furniture
subtitle: movable objects for comfort or utility.

title: Clothing
subtitle: items worn on the body.

title: Upper Body Garment (Tops)
subtitle: Garments primarily designed to cover the torso and/or arms.

title: Shirt
subtitle: A garment with a collar, sleeves, and a full-length opening at the front, typically fastened with buttons.

title: T-Shirt
subtitle: A collarless, short-sleeved garment of T-shape, usually made of cotton jersey.

title: Sweater
subtitle: A knitted garment worn on the upper body, typically pulled over the head or buttoned/zippered at the front.

title: Blouse
subtitle: A loose-fitting upper garment for women or children, typically gathered at the waist or hips.

title: Vest
subtitle: A sleeveless upper-body garment that covers the torso.

title: Lower Body Garment (Bottoms)
subtitle: Garments primarily designed to cover the waist, hips, and/or legs.

title: Pants (Trousers)
subtitle: A garment covering the body from the waist to the ankles, with a separate covering for each leg.

title: Skirt
subtitle: A garment hanging from the waist and covering all or part of the legs, forming the lower part of a dress or worn separately.

title: Shorts
subtitle: A garment similar to pants but with legs that extend only to the thigh or knee.

title: Skort
subtitle: A hybrid garment consisting of shorts with a fabric panel resembling a skirt covering the front (and sometimes the back), combining the appearance of a skirt with the practicality of shorts.

title: One-Piece Garment
subtitle: Garments that combine coverage for both the upper and lower body in a single, connected piece.

title: Dress
subtitle: A single garment that covers the body and extends down over the legs, typically worn by women.

title: Jumpsuit
subtitle: A one-piece garment that combines a top with pants, typically worn by women.

title: Romper
subtitle: A one-piece garment combining a top with shorts, typically worn by women or children.

title: Overalls
subtitle: A one-piece garment consisting of trousers with a bib attached, typically worn as workwear.

title: Outerwear
subtitle: Garments worn as the outermost layer, primarily for warmth, protection from elements, or fashion.

title: Coat
subtitle: A long outer garment, typically worn over other clothes for warmth or protection.

title: Jacket
subtitle: A short coat, often extending to the waist or hips, worn for warmth, protection, or fashion.

title: Undergarment
subtitle: Garments worn directly against the skin, underneath outer clothing, for hygiene, support, warmth, or modesty.

title: Underwear
subtitle: Garments worn on the lower body or torso beneath outer clothing.

title: Bra (Brassiere)
subtitle: An undergarment worn by women to support or cover the breasts.

title: Undershirt
subtitle: A shirt worn next to the skin, typically under a shirt or other top.

title: Sleepwear
subtitle: Garments specifically designed to be worn while sleeping.

title: Footwear
subtitle: Items primarily designed to be worn on the feet for protection, comfort, and fashion.

title: Shoes
subtitle: Outer coverings for the feet, typically ending below the ankle.

title: Boots
subtitle: Footwear that extends up the ankle, leg, or thigh.

title: Sandals
subtitle: Footwear consisting of a sole held to the foot by straps or thongs.

title: Headwear
subtitle: Items primarily designed to be worn on the head.

title: Hat
subtitle: A shaped covering for the head, typically with a brim and/or crown.

title: Cap
subtitle: A soft, close-fitting head covering, often with a visor.

title: Handwear
subtitle: Items primarily designed to be worn on the hands.

title: Gloves
subtitle: A covering for the hand having separate sheaths for each finger and the thumb.

title: Mittens
subtitle: A covering for the hand having a separate enclosure for the thumb but a single enclosure for all four fingers.

title: Hosiery
subtitle: Close-fitting, often elastic garments covering the foot and/or leg, worn under other clothing.

title: Socks
subtitle: A garment worn on the foot, usually extending to the ankle or part of the calf.

title: Stockings
subtitle: Close-fitting garments covering the foot and leg, extending higher than socks.

title: Swimwear
subtitle: Garments designed for swimming or other water-based activities.

title: Weapon
subtitle: an artificial object designed or adapted to inflict damage, harm, or death to living beings, or to destroy or incapacitate objects, typically used for offense, defense, or deterrence in conflict or combat situations.

title: Bladed Weapon
subtitle: a weapon featuring one or more sharpened edges or points, designed or adapted for cutting, slashing, stabbing, or thrusting.

title: Sword
subtitle: a long-bladed weapon intended for slashing, thrusting, or both.

title: Longsword
subtitle: a European double-edged sword with a cruciform hilt, used with two hands.

title: Broadsword
subtitle: a European sword with a wide, straight, double-edged blade.

title: Sabre
subtitle: a curved, single-edged sword with a hand guard, used primarily for slashing.

title: Rapier
subtitle: a slender, sharply pointed sword, optimized for thrusting.

title: Katana
subtitle: a Japanese curved, single-edged sword with a circular or squared guard.

title: Wakizashi
subtitle: a Japanese short sword, companion to the katana.

title: Tachi
subtitle: a Japanese curved sword, predecessor to the katana, worn edge-down.

title: Uchigatana
subtitle: a Japanese sword with a curved blade, worn edge-up.

title: Scimitar
subtitle: a Middle Eastern curved, single-edged sword.

title: Falchion
subtitle: a European single-edged, broad-bladed sword.

title: Cutlass
subtitle: a short, broad sabre with a straight or slightly curved blade, used by sailors.

title: Claymore
subtitle: a large Scottish two-handed sword with a cross hilt.

title: Jian
subtitle: a double-edged straight sword from China.

title: Dao
subtitle: a single-edged Chinese sword, often with a curved blade.

title: Gladius
subtitle: a short Roman double-edged sword for stabbing.

title: Spatha
subtitle: a longer Roman sword, used by cavalry and infantry.

title: Xiphos
subtitle: a short, double-edged Greek sword.

title: Kopis
subtitle: a Greek single-edged, forward-curving sword.

title: Kukri
subtitle: a Nepalese inwardly curved, single-edged sword.

title: Messer
subtitle: a German single-edged sword, resembling a large knife.

title: Shamshir
subtitle: a Persian curved, single-edged sword.

title: Talwar
subtitle: an Indian curved, single-edged sword.

title: Ulfberht
subtitle: a type of high-quality Viking Age sword.

title: Zweihander
subtitle: a large German two-handed sword.

title: Estoc
subtitle: a European sword with a long, narrow, pointed blade for thrusting.

title: Shotel
subtitle: an Ethiopian sword with a strongly curved blade.

title: Khopesh
subtitle: an Egyptian sickle-sword with a curved blade.

title: Makraka
subtitle: an African sword with a distinctive curved blade.

title: Flamberge
subtitle: a sword with a wavy, flame-like blade.

title: Backsword
subtitle: a sword with a single-edged blade and a flat back.

title: Basket-hilted sword
subtitle: a sword with a basket-shaped guard to protect the hand.

title: Cinquedea
subtitle: a short, broad-bladed Italian sword.

title: Kopesh
subtitle: an alternate spelling of khopesh, see 3.1.2.2.7.1.1.27.

title: Parang
subtitle: a Malaysian/Indonesian sword with a broad, curved blade.

title: Yatagan
subtitle: a Turkish sword with a double-curved blade.

title: Kris
subtitle: a Southeast Asian sword with a wavy blade.

title: Mameluke sword
subtitle: a curved, cross-hilted sword of Middle Eastern origin.

title: Patissa
subtitle: an ancient Indian straight sword.

title: Shashka
subtitle: a single-edged, curved sword from the Caucasus.

title: Kilij
subtitle: a Turkish sabre with a slightly curved blade.

title: Dagger
subtitle: a short, pointed, double-edged blade designed for stabbing or thrusting.

title: Dirk
subtitle: a long thrusting dagger, especially of Scottish origin.

title: Stiletto
subtitle: a slender dagger with a needle-like point, designed for stabbing.

title: Kris (Keris)
subtitle: a Southeast Asian dagger with a wavy blade.

title: Pugio
subtitle: a Roman dagger with a broad, leaf-shaped blade.

title: Rondel dagger
subtitle: a medieval European dagger with a round guard and pommel.

title: Bollock dagger
subtitle: a dagger with a distinctively shaped hilt, popular in medieval Europe.

title: Baselard
subtitle: a late medieval dagger with a characteristic H-shaped hilt.

title: Jambiya
subtitle: a curved, double-edged dagger from the Middle East.

title: Khanjar
subtitle: a curved, double-edged dagger from Oman and surrounding regions.

title: Parazonium
subtitle: a Roman ceremonial dagger.

title: Seax
subtitle: a Germanic single-edged knife or dagger.

title: Misericorde
subtitle: a long, narrow dagger used to deliver the death stroke.

title: Couteau de chasse
subtitle: a French hunting dagger.

title: Push dagger
subtitle: a dagger with a T-shaped handle for punching.

title: Trench knife
subtitle: a combat knife with a knuckle guard, used in trench warfare.

title: Knife
subtitle: a bladed weapon with a single edge, typically shorter than a sword.

title: Bowie knife
subtitle: a large, fixed-blade fighting knife.

title: Combat knife
subtitle: a knife designed for military use in close combat.

title: Trench knife
subtitle: a combat knife with a knuckle guard, used in trench warfare.

title: Bayonet
subtitle: a blade that can be attached to the muzzle of a rifle.

title: Machete
subtitle: a broad, heavy knife used for cutting vegetation and as a weapon.

title: Kukri
subtitle: a Nepalese inwardly curved, single-edged knife.

title: Karambit
subtitle: a small, curved knife from Southeast Asia.

title: Tanto
subtitle: a Japanese short, single or double-edged knife.

title: Dirk
subtitle: a long thrusting knife, especially of Scottish origin.

title: Stiletto
subtitle: a slender knife with a needle-like point.

title: Spearhead/Bladed Polearm
subtitle: a pole weapon with a bladed head for thrusting, slashing, or both.

title: Spear
subtitle: a pole weapon with a pointed, bladed head for thrusting.

title: Lance
subtitle: a long spear used by cavalry.

title: Halberd
subtitle: a polearm with an axe blade topped with a spike.

title: Glaive
subtitle: a polearm with a single-edged blade on the end.

title: Naginata
subtitle: a Japanese polearm with a curved blade.

title: Guandao
subtitle: a Chinese polearm with a broad, curved blade.

title: Bardiche
subtitle: a long poleaxe with a large, curved blade.

title: Partisan
subtitle: a polearm with a broad, double-edged blade.

title: Spetum
subtitle: a polearm with a long, flat blade and two prongs.

title: Ranseur
subtitle: a polearm with a central blade and two lateral projections.

title: Fauchard
subtitle: a polearm with a curved blade, similar to a scythe.

title: Billhook
subtitle: a polearm with a hooked blade.

title: Voulge
subtitle: a polearm with a broad, cleaver-like blade.

title: Guisarme
subtitle: a polearm with a hook and spike.

title: Lochaber axe
subtitle: a Scottish polearm with a broad blade and hook.

title: Sovnya
subtitle: a Russian polearm with a curved, single-edged blade.

title: Sickle
subtitle: a short, curved blade mounted on a pole, used as a weapon.

title: Kama
subtitle: a Japanese sickle-like weapon, often used in pairs.

title: Hook sword
subtitle: a Chinese sword with a hook-shaped blade, often used in pairs.

title: Axe/Hatchet
subtitle: a weapon with a bladed head mounted on a handle, used for chopping or cleaving.

title: Battle axe
subtitle: a large axe designed for combat.

title: Tomahawk
subtitle: a small, single-handed axe from North America.

title: Dane axe
subtitle: a long-handled axe used by Vikings.

title: Francisca
subtitle: a throwing axe used by the Franks.

title: Labrys
subtitle: a double-headed axe from ancient Crete.

title: Bardiche
subtitle: a long poleaxe with a large, curved blade.

title: Tabar
subtitle: a Persian battle axe.

title: Sagaris
subtitle: a single-bladed axe from ancient Persia.

title: Flexible Sword
subtitle: a sword with a flexible or whip-like blade.

title: Urumi
subtitle: a South Indian sword with a flexible, whip-like blade.

title: Gauntlet Sword
subtitle: a sword integrated with a gauntlet.

title: Pata (gauntlet sword)
subtitle: an Indian sword with a straight blade attached to a gauntlet.

title: Exotic Bladed Weapon
subtitle: a bladed weapon with a unique or unusual form.

title: Emeici
subtitle: a pair of Chinese metal rods with sharp ends, used for stabbing.

title: Bagh nakh
subtitle: an Indian weapon with claw-like blades worn on the hand.

title: Katar
subtitle: an Indian push dagger with a H-shaped handle.

title: Haladie
subtitle: a double-edged dagger from India with two blades.

title: Macuahuitl
subtitle: an Aztec weapon with obsidian blades embedded in a wooden club.

title: Yatagan
subtitle: a Turkish sword with a double-curved blade.

title: Kris sword
subtitle: a Southeast Asian sword with a wavy blade.

title: Khanda
subtitle: a double-edged straight sword from India.

title: Dha
subtitle: a single-edged sword from Southeast Asia.

title: Flyssa
subtitle: a long, narrow-bladed sword from Algeria.

title: Falx
subtitle: a curved, sickle-like sword from Dacia.

title: Projectile Weapon
subtitle: a weapon that propels a projectile by mechanical, chemical, or other means to strike a distant target.

title: Thrown Projectile
subtitle: a projectile weapon propelled by manual throwing force.

title: Javelin
subtitle: a light spear designed to be thrown.

title: Throwing axe
subtitle: a small axe designed for throwing.

title: Throwing hammer
subtitle: a hammer-like weapon designed to be thrown.

title: Boomerang
subtitle: a curved, aerodynamic throwing tool that returns to the thrower.

title: Shuriken
subtitle: a star-shaped Japanese throwing weapon.

title: Chakram
subtitle: a circular throwing weapon with a sharpened rim from India.

title: Throwing knife
subtitle: a knife optimized for throwing accuracy.

title: Bow
subtitle: a ranged weapon using tension in a flexible arc to launch arrows.

title: Longbow
subtitle: a tall, powerful bow with long, straight limbs.

title: Recurve bow
subtitle: a bow with limbs that curve away from the archer when unstrung.

title: Compound bow
subtitle: a bow that uses a system of pulleys and cams for mechanical advantage.

title: Crossbow
subtitle: a bow mounted on a stock that shoots bolts.

title: Arbalest
subtitle: a powerful crossbow with a heavy steel prod.

title: Repeating crossbow
subtitle: a crossbow with a magazine for multiple bolts.

title: Firearm
subtitle: a weapon that launches a projectile by explosive force.

title: Handgun
subtitle: a small firearm designed to be held and operated with one hand.

title: Pistol
subtitle: a semi-automatic handgun with a detachable magazine.

title: Revolver
subtitle: a handgun with a rotating cylinder that holds cartridges.

title: Derringer
subtitle: a small, easily concealable single-shot pistol.

title: Rifle
subtitle: a long-barreled firearm with a rifled bore for accuracy.

title: Bolt-action rifle
subtitle: a rifle manually operated by a bolt mechanism.

title: Lever-action rifle
subtitle: a rifle that uses a lever integrated into the stock to cycle cartridges.

title: Semi-automatic rifle
subtitle: a rifle that fires one cartridge per trigger pull and automatically cycles.

title: Assault rifle
subtitle: a selective-fire rifle using intermediate cartridges and detachable magazines.

title: Shotgun
subtitle: a smoothbore firearm designed to fire multiple projectiles.

title: Pump-action shotgun
subtitle: a shotgun that uses a sliding fore-end for cycling cartridges.

title: Break-action shotgun
subtitle: a shotgun with a hinged barrel that opens for loading.

title: Semi-automatic shotgun
subtitle: a shotgun that automatically cycles to load the next round.

title: Machine gun
subtitle: an automatic firearm capable of sustained fire.

title: Light machine gun
subtitle: a portable machine gun designed for infantry support.

title: Medium machine gun
subtitle: a machine gun that fires full-power rifle cartridges at sustained rates.

title: Heavy machine gun
subtitle: a large, crew-served machine gun that fires heavy-caliber ammunition.

title: Siege Engine
subtitle: a large-scale weapon for attacking fortifications.

title: Catapult
subtitle: a device that hurls projectiles using tension, torsion, or gravity.

title: Trebuchet
subtitle: a counterweight-driven siege engine that launches heavy missiles.

title: Ballista
subtitle: a torsion-powered siege weapon that launches large bolts.

title: Onager
subtitle: a Roman torsion-powered catapult that hurls stones.

title: Sling
subtitle: a weapon using a pouch and cords to hurl a stone or lead weight.

title: Blowgun
subtitle: a tube through which a projectile is expelled by breath.

title: Thrown explosive
subtitle: a hand-thrown device containing explosive or incendiary components.

title: Grenade
subtitle: a small explosive device designed to be thrown by hand or launched.

title: Molotov cocktail
subtitle: a breakable glass bottle containing incendiary liquids for improvised use.

title: Smoke grenade
subtitle: a device that emits smoke for signaling or concealment.

title: Flashbang
subtitle: a non-lethal device producing a blinding flash and loud noise to disorient.

title: Physical Field
subtitle: spatially extended continuous entities

title: Gravitational Field
subtitle: region where mass experiences force.

title: Electromagnetic Field
subtitle: unified field of electric and magnetic effects.

title: Quantum Field
subtitle: fundamental entity in quantum field theory.

title: Scalar Field
subtitle: assigns scalar value to each point.

title: Vector Field
subtitle: assigns vector to each point.

title: Tensor Field
subtitle: assigns tensor to each point.

title: Physical System
subtitle: integrated assemblies of entities

title: Mechanical System
subtitle: concerned with motion, force, energy.

title: Thermal System
subtitle: concerned with heat and temperature.

title: Chemical System
subtitle: involves chemical reactions and substances.

title: Biological System
subtitle: network of interacting biological entities.

title: Electrical System
subtitle: involves flow of electric charge.

title: Optical System
subtitle: manipulates or detects light.

title: Ecological System
subtitle: community of organisms and environment.

title: Astronomical System
subtitle: collection of celestial objects gravitationally bound.

title: Physical Attribute
subtitle: inherent qualities or aspects of entities

title: Physical Property
subtitle: measurable attributes

title: Fundamental Quantity
subtitle: basic measurable quantity, not derived.

title: Derived Quantity
subtitle: quantity defined from fundamental quantities.

title: Material Property
subtitle: property inherent to a specific material.

title: Thermodynamic Property
subtitle: property related to heat, temperature, energy.

title: Electromagnetic Property
subtitle: property related to electric and magnetic fields.

title: Optical Property
subtitle: property describing interaction with light.

title: Energy Form
subtitle: specific manifestations of energy

title: Kinetic Energy
subtitle: energy of motion.

title: Potential Energy
subtitle: stored energy based on position or state.

title: Thermal Energy
subtitle: energy associated with temperature of substance.

title: Chemical Energy
subtitle: energy stored in chemical bonds.

title: Nuclear Energy
subtitle: energy stored in atomic nuclei.

title: Radiant Energy
subtitle: energy of electromagnetic waves (e.g., light).

title: Physical State
subtitle: distinct conditions or configurations

title: Solid State
subtitle: rigid structure, definite shape and volume.

title: Liquid State
subtitle: definite volume, takes container shape.

title: Gas State
subtitle: no definite shape or volume.

title: Plasma State
subtitle: ionized gas, behaves collectively under fields.

title: Metastable State
subtitle: non-equilibrium state with long lifetime.

title: Excited State
subtitle: higher energy state than ground state.

title: Ground State
subtitle: lowest energy state of system.

title: Physical Structure
subtitle: recurring spatial arrangements

title: Crystalline Structure
subtitle: highly ordered atomic/molecular arrangement.

title: Cellular Structure
subtitle: organized assembly of cells in biology.

title: Network Structure
subtitle: interconnected nodes and edges.

title: Fractal Structure
subtitle: self-similar patterns at different scales.

title: Molecular Structure
subtitle: arrangement of atoms within a molecule.

title: Architectural Structure
subtitle: designed arrangement of building components.

title: Physical Dynamics
subtitle: active behaviors and changes

title: Physical Interaction
subtitle: force-mediated couplings

title: Gravitational Interaction
subtitle: attractive force between masses.

title: Electromagnetic Interaction
subtitle: force between charged particles.

title: Strong Nuclear Interaction
subtitle: force binding nucleons in nucleus.

title: Weak Nuclear Interaction
subtitle: force involved in radioactive decay.

title: Frictional Interaction
subtitle: force opposing relative motion.

title: Elastic Interaction
subtitle: interaction where entities deform and return.

title: Physical Process
subtitle: time-directed sequences of change

title: Mechanical Process
subtitle: process involving forces and motion.

title: Thermal Process
subtitle: process involving heat transfer or temperature change.

title: Chemical Process
subtitle: process involving chemical reactions.

title: Nuclear Process
subtitle: process involving changes in atomic nuclei.

title: Phase Transition Process
subtitle: process changing physical state of matter.

title: Biological Process
subtitle: process occurring within living organisms.

title: Geological Process
subtitle: process shaping the Earth's surface/interior.

title: Physical Phenomenon
subtitle: observable manifestations

title: Wave Phenomenon
subtitle: behavior of waves (e.g., interference, diffraction).

title: Quantum Phenomenon
subtitle: behavior at atomic/subatomic scale.

title: Electromagnetic Phenomenon
subtitle: phenomena involving electric and magnetic fields.

title: Thermal Phenomenon
subtitle: phenomena involving heat and temperature.

title: Optical Phenomenon
subtitle: phenomena involving light and vision.

title: Acoustic Phenomenon
subtitle: phenomena involving sound and vibration.

title: Information Carrier
subtitle: substrates and channels that hold or convey information

title: Transmission Channel
subtitle: a pathway for information in transit

title: Digital Communication Channel
subtitle: e.g. fiber-optic link, Ethernet

title: Analog Communication Channel
subtitle: e.g. radio wave, analog audio line

title: Biological Communication Channel
subtitle: e.g. neural spike train, DNA messaging

title: Storage Medium
subtitle: a physical or virtual substrate for stored information

title: Physical Storage Medium
subtitle: e.g. paper, magnetic tape, optical disc

title: Solid-State Storage Medium
subtitle: e.g. SSD, flash memory

title: Biological Storage Medium
subtitle: e.g. DNA store, neural pattern

title: Mental
subtitle: The realm of mind, encompassing consciousness, cognition, affect, and volition

title: Mental State
subtitle: a distinct condition or mode of the mind or subjective experience

title: Affective State
subtitle: a state of feeling, mood, or emotional experience

title: Emotion
subtitle: A relatively brief, intense, and often specific affective state, typically involving physiological arousal, expressive behaviors, and conscious experience, often triggered by a particular internal or external stimulus or event.

title: Joy
subtitle: An emotion characterized by intense feelings of elation, pleasure, or delight, often in response to a specific positive event or realization.

title: Happiness
subtitle: An emotion characterized by a more general and sustained state of contentment, satisfaction, and positive well-being.

title: Sadness
subtitle: An emotion characterized by feelings of loss, disadvantage, sorrow, or helplessness.

title: Anger
subtitle: An emotion characterized by feelings of displeasure, antagonism, or hostility, often resulting from perceived provocation, hurt, or threat.

title: Fear
subtitle: An emotion characterized by feelings of apprehension, dread, or alarm, typically triggered by perceived danger or threat.

title: Surprise
subtitle: An emotion characterized by a brief state of astonishment or wonder, typically elicited by an unexpected event.

title: Disgust
subtitle: An emotion characterized by feelings of revulsion or strong disapproval, often in response to something offensive, distasteful, or contaminating.

title: Interest
subtitle: An emotion characterized by a feeling of engagement, focused attention, and concern towards a stimulus or subject, often due to its perceived relevance or importance.

title: Curiosity
subtitle: An emotion characterized by a strong desire to know, learn, or explore something new, unknown, or intriguing, often motivating investigation.

title: Love (Emotional State)
subtitle: A complex emotion characterized by deep affection, care, attachment, and often intimacy towards another being or entity. (Distinguished from love as a broader sentiment or relationship construct).

title: Shame
subtitle: A self-conscious emotion characterized by painful feelings of humiliation or distress caused by the consciousness of wrong or foolish behavior, or a perceived inadequacy.

title: Guilt
subtitle: A self-conscious emotion characterized by feelings of culpability or remorse for a perceived offense, transgression, or wrongdoing.

title: Pride
subtitle: A self-conscious emotion characterized by feelings of deep pleasure or satisfaction derived from one's own achievements, qualities, or possessions, or those of someone with whom one is closely associated.

title: Contempt
subtitle: An emotion characterized by feelings of disdain, scorn, or disrespect for someone or something regarded as worthless or inferior.

title: Gratitude
subtitle: An emotion characterized by feelings of thankfulness and appreciation in response to receiving a benefit from another.

title: Hope
subtitle: An emotion characterized by an expectation and desire for a certain positive outcome.

title: Jealousy
subtitle: A complex emotion characterized by feelings of insecurity, fear, and concern over an anticipated loss of something of personal value, particularly in the context of a human relationship.

title: Envy
subtitle: An emotion characterized by a painful or resentful awareness of an advantage enjoyed by another, coupled with a desire to possess the same advantage.

title: Frustration
subtitle: An emotion experienced when an anticipated goal or action is blocked or prevented.

title: Relief
subtitle: An emotion experienced upon the removal of distress, pain, or anxiety.

title: Regret
subtitle: An emotion characterized by sadness, repentance, or disappointment over something that has happened or been done, especially a loss or missed opportunity.

title: Awe
subtitle: An emotion characterized by feelings of reverential respect mixed with fear or wonder, often elicited by something perceived as vast, sublime, or powerful.

title: Amusement
subtitle: An emotion characterized by finding something funny or entertaining, often accompanied by smiling or laughter.

title: Excitement
subtitle: An emotion characterized by feelings of great enthusiasm and eagerness.

title: Contentment
subtitle: An emotion characterized by a state of peaceful satisfaction and ease.

title: Compassion
subtitle: An emotion characterized by a deep awareness of and empathy for the suffering of another, coupled with a strong motivation to alleviate that suffering.

title: Sympathy
subtitle: An emotion characterized by feelings of concern, care, and understanding for someone else's sorrow or misfortune, acknowledging their distress.

title: Mood
subtitle: A prolonged, less intense, and more diffuse affective state that is not necessarily tied to a specific object or event, often coloring one's overall subjective experience and outlook for a period.

title: Euthymic Mood
subtitle: A relatively stable mood state characterized by a sense of normalcy, calmness, and absence of marked elevation or depression. (Baseline mood).

title: Elevated Mood / Euphoric Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by an exaggerated feeling of well-being, elation, or happiness, often disproportionate to circumstances.

title: Elated Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by intense happiness, joy, or high spirits, often slightly less extreme or enduring than full euphoria.

title: Exuberant Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by energetic enthusiasm, vivacity, and lively expression.

title: Hypomanic Mood
subtitle: A persistent, pervasive, and often disruptive elevated, expansive, or irritable mood that is less severe than full mania, typically without significant functional impairment or psychotic features.

title: Manic Mood
subtitle: A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, and abnormally and persistently increased goal-directed activity or energy, lasting at least 1 week and present most of the day, nearly every day.

title: Dysphoric Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by general feelings of unease, dissatisfaction, unhappiness, or sadness.

title: Uneasy Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by general discomfort, restlessness, or a feeling that something is wrong, without a clear cause.

title: Dissatisfied Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by a general sense of disappointment or unfulfillment.

title: Pessimistic Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by a tendency to expect the worst possible outcome or to dwell on the negative aspects of a situation.

title: Depressed Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, emptiness, hopelessness, or loss of interest or pleasure. (Can be a symptom of a disorder or a standalone mood state).

title: Anhedonic Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by a significant loss of interest or pleasure in activities that were once considered enjoyable.

title: Melancholic Mood
subtitle: A severe form of depressed mood characterized by distinct quality of mood, profound despair, psychomotor retardation or agitation, and other specific somatic symptoms (often a specifier in clinical depression).

title: Apathetic-Depressed Mood
subtitle: Depressed mood combined with a predominant lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern.

title: Irritable Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by a propensity to be easily annoyed, angered, or agitated.

title: Agitated-Irritable Mood
subtitle: Irritable mood accompanied by increased psychomotor activity, restlessness, or inner tension.

title: Hostile Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by feelings of antagonism or unfriendliness, often expressed through aggressive behavior or thoughts.

title: Anxious Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by sustained feelings of apprehension, worry, nervousness, or unease, often about an impending event or something with an uncertain outcome.

title: Generalized Anxious Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by pervasive, non-specific worry and apprehension about a variety of things.

title: Apprehensive Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by a specific anticipation of impending danger, misfortune, or unpleasantness.

title: Panicked Mood
subtitle: A sudden, intense mood characterized by overwhelming fear, terror, or dread, often accompanied by physical symptoms.

title: Apathetic Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by a lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern; indifference.

title: Indifferent Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by a lack of interest or concern, often more neutral than true apathy.

title: Listless Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by a lack of energy, enthusiasm, or spirit; sluggishness.

title: Expansive Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by unceasing and indiscriminate enthusiasm for interpersonal, sexual, or occupational interactions, often associated with an overestimation of one's importance or capabilities.

title: Calm Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by tranquility, serenity, and freedom from agitation or disturbance.

title: Relaxed Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by a state of being free from tension and anxiety.

title: Peaceful Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by a sense of inner quiet and freedom from disturbance.

title: Tense Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by feelings of mental or nervous strain, stress, or suspense.

title: Stressed Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by feelings of pressure, demandingness, or being overwhelmed by circumstances.

title: Nervous Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by unease or apprehension, often accompanied by physical signs of anxiety.

title: Energetic Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by having or showing great activity or vitality.

title: Enthusiastic Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by intense and eager enjoyment, interest, or approval.

title: Vigorous Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by physical or mental strength, health, and energy.

title: Fatigued Mood / Lethargic Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by a lack of energy and enthusiasm, weariness, or sluggishness.

title: Drained Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by feeling completely exhausted or devoid of energy.

title: Sluggish Mood
subtitle: A mood characterized by feeling noticeably slow, lacking in energy or alertness.

title: Sensory State
subtitle: a state of subjective experience derived from sensory input

title: Visual Sensation
subtitle: subjective experience from visual input.

title: Color Perception
subtitle: the subjective experience of hue, saturation, and brightness derived from light wavelengths.

title: Form Perception
subtitle: the subjective experience of shapes, outlines, and spatial arrangements of objects.

title: Motion Perception
subtitle: the subjective experience of movement or changes in position.

title: Light Intensity Perception
subtitle: the subjective experience of brightness or dimness.

title: Auditory Sensation
subtitle: subjective experience from sound input.

title: Pitch Perception
subtitle: the subjective experience of how high or low a sound is, related to frequency.

title: Loudness Perception
subtitle: the subjective experience of the intensity or volume of a sound, related to amplitude.

title: Timbre Perception
subtitle: the subjective experience of the quality or character of a sound that distinguishes different types of sound production (e.g., musical instruments, voices).

title: Spatial Audition
subtitle: the subjective experience of where a sound originates in space.

title: Olfactory Sensation
subtitle: subjective experience from smell input.

title: Odor Quality Perception
subtitle: the subjective experience of distinct types of smells.

title: Odor Intensity Perception
subtitle: the subjective experience of the strength or concentration of a smell.

title: Gustatory Sensation
subtitle: subjective experience from taste input.

title: Basic Taste Qualities
subtitle: the subjective experience of the fundamental tastes recognized by the tongue.

title: Flavor Perception
subtitle: the complex subjective experience resulting from the combination of taste, smell (through retronasal olfaction), and often touch (texture) and temperature in the mouth.

title: Somatosensory Sensation
subtitle: subjective experience from bodily senses (touch, pain, temperature, proprioception, kinesthesia).

title: Tactile Perception (Touch)
subtitle: the subjective experience of pressure, vibration, texture, or contact on the skin.

title: Nociception (Pain Perception)
subtitle: the subjective experience of discomfort or unpleasant sensations arising from tissue damage or potential damage.

title: Thermoception (Temperature Perception)
subtitle: the subjective experience of heat or cold on the skin or internally.

title: Proprioception
subtitle: the subjective experience of the relative position of one's own body parts and strength of effort being used in movement, derived from internal receptors.

title: Kinesthesia
subtitle: the subjective experience of movement of body parts.

title: Vestibular Sensation
subtitle: subjective experience from balance/orientation system.

title: Balance Perception
subtitle: the subjective experience of maintaining equilibrium and spatial stability.

title: Head Position/Movement Perception
subtitle: the subjective experience of the orientation and acceleration of the head in space.

title: Interoceptive Sensation
subtitle: subjective experience of internal bodily states.

title: Visceral Sensation
subtitle: the subjective experience of internal organ states.

title: Bodily Homeostasis Perception
subtitle: the subjective experience related to the body's internal regulatory processes.

title: Mental Process
subtitle: an operation or sequence of changes occurring in the mind

title: Cognitive Process
subtitle: a mental operation involved in acquiring, processing, or using knowledge and information

title: Perceptual Process
subtitle: interpreting sensory information.

title: Attentional Process
subtitle: selecting and focusing on stimuli.

title: Sustained Attention
subtitle: maintaining focus over time.

title: Selective Attention
subtitle: focusing on specific stimuli among others.

title: Attentional Lapse
subtitle: temporary failure of attention.

title: Memory Process
subtitle: an operation involved in encoding, storing, or retrieving information

title: Episodic Memory Process
subtitle: processing personal events with context.

title: Semantic Memory Process
subtitle: processing general world knowledge.

title: Procedural Memory Process
subtitle: processing skills and habits.

title: Autobiographical Memory Process
subtitle: processing personal past events.

title: Thinking Process
subtitle: manipulating information to reason, solve problems.

title: Reasoning Process
subtitle: drawing conclusions from information.

title: Learning Process
subtitle: acquiring new knowledge or skills.

title: Metacognitive Process
subtitle: thinking about one's own thinking.

title: Time-Perception Process
subtitle: subjective experience of duration.

title: Interval-Timing Process
subtitle: judging duration of intervals.

title: Social Cognitive Process
subtitle: a cognitive process involved in understanding and interacting with the social world

title: Theory of Mind
subtitle: understanding others' mental states.

title: Empathy (as a cognitive process component)
subtitle: cognitively understanding others' feelings.

title: Social Attribution Process
subtitle: explaining others' behavior.

title: Stereotyping Process
subtitle: applying generalized beliefs to groups.

title: Volitional Process
subtitle: a mental operation related to will, motivation, and goal-directed action

title: Motivational Process
subtitle: driving behavior towards goals.

title: Intention Formation Process
subtitle: developing plans to act.

title: Decision-Making Process
subtitle: choosing among options.

title: Self-Control Process
subtitle: regulating impulses and behavior.

title: Executive Function Process
subtitle: higher-level cognitive control processes.

title: Communicative Process
subtitle: a mental operation involved in the exchange of information or meaning

title: Language Production Process
subtitle: generating spoken or written language.

title: Language Comprehension Process
subtitle: understanding spoken or written language.

title: Inner Speech Process
subtitle: internal verbal thinking.

title: Nonverbal Communication Process
subtitle: communicating without words.

title: Social Communicative Interaction Process
subtitle: exchanging meaning in social contexts.

title: Developmental Process
subtitle: a mental operation reflecting change over time in mental capacities or functioning

title: Cognitive Development Process
subtitle: changes in thinking over lifespan.

title: Expertise Acquisition Process
subtitle: developing high proficiency in skill.

title: Cognitive Aging Process
subtitle: changes in cognition with age.

title: Creative Process
subtitle: a mental operation involved in generating novel and valuable ideas or products

title: Divergent Thinking Process
subtitle: generating multiple possible solutions.

title: Convergent Thinking Process
subtitle: finding single best solution.

title: Problem-Solving Process
subtitle: finding solutions to obstacles.

title: Emotional Regulation Process
subtitle: a mental operation to influence the experience or expression of emotion

title: Mental Content
subtitle: information, beliefs, or representations held within the mind

title: Mental Representation
subtitle: a mental structure that stands for something else

title: Mental Imagery
subtitle: a sensory-like representation generated internally, often resembling the experience of actual perception.

title: Sensory Modality-Specific Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery primarily associated with a particular sensory system.

title: Visual Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery based on sight, including objects, scenes, and spatial layouts.

title: Eidetic Imagery
subtitle: unusually vivid, detailed, and persistent visual recall, akin to "photographic memory."

title: Fantastical Visual Imagery
subtitle: visual imagery of non-existent or impossible scenes (e.g., hallucinations, dreams).

title: Auditory Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery based on sound, including voices, music, environmental sounds.

title: Musical Imagery
subtitle: internal experience of melodies, harmonies, and rhythms.

title: Verbal Imagery
subtitle: internal "hearing" of words or speech.

title: Olfactory Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery based on smell (e.g., recalling the scent of coffee).

title: Gustatory Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery based on taste (e.g., recalling the taste of lemon).

title: Somatosensory Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery based on bodily sensations.

title: Tactile Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery of touch sensations (e.g., texture, pressure).

title: Kinesthetic Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery of bodily movement or position (e.g., imagining walking).

title: Thermal Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery of temperature sensations (e.g., imagining warmth or cold).

title: Pain Imagery
subtitle: mental imagery of pain sensations.

title: Mental Model
subtitle: an internal, dynamic representation of a system, situation, or phenomenon that allows for understanding, prediction, and explanation.

title: Domain-Specific Mental Model
subtitle: a mental model tailored to a particular area of knowledge or activity.

title: System Mental Model
subtitle: a mental model of how a particular physical or abstract system operates (e.g., a car engine, computer software).

title: Functional Mental Model
subtitle: represents the purpose and intended behavior of system components.

title: Structural Mental Model
subtitle: represents the physical or logical arrangement of system components.

title: Process Mental Model
subtitle: represents the sequence of operations or transformations within a system.

title: Task Mental Model
subtitle: a mental model of how to perform a specific task, including goals, steps, and required resources.

title: Social Mental Model
subtitle: a mental model of social interactions, group dynamics, or societal structures.

title: Other Minds Model (Theory of Mind)
subtitle: model of the beliefs, intentions, and desires of other individuals.

title: Group Dynamics Model
subtitle: model of how groups behave and interact.

title: Situational Model
subtitle: a dynamic mental model representing the current state and likely future states of an immediate environment or context.

title: Current State Model
subtitle: represents what is happening now in the situation.

title: Environmental State Model
subtitle: model of the physical surroundings and their properties (e.g., weather, terrain).

title: System State Model (Situational Context)
subtitle: model of the current configuration and operational status of relevant systems within the situation.

title: Agent State Model (Situational Context)
subtitle: model of the current internal states (e.g., location, actions, immediate goals) of other agents involved in the situation.

title: Future State Model
subtitle: represents predictions or projections of how the situation will evolve.

title: Trend Extrapolation Model
subtitle: projection based on observed patterns or trajectories (e.g., speed and direction of a moving object).

title: Event Prediction Model
subtitle: anticipation of specific future events or outcomes (e.g., a collision, a change in system status).

title: Consequence Projection Model
subtitle: mental simulation of the potential results of one's own actions or external events on the situation.

title: Explanatory Model
subtitle: represents the underlying reasons, causes, or constraints for the current situation.

title: Causal Attribution Model
subtitle: understanding why events or behaviors occurred within the situation.

title: Anomaly Explanation Model
subtitle: providing a reason or rationale for unexpected or unusual observations in the situation.

title: Conceptual Category
subtitle: a mental grouping of distinct entities (objects, events, ideas) based on shared properties, relationships, or functions.

title: Formation Basis of Category
subtitle: how a conceptual category is acquired or structured.

title: Natural Kind Concept
subtitle: a conceptual category referring to naturally occurring groupings whose members share intrinsic properties (e.g., "bird," "water," "tree").

title: Artifact Concept
subtitle: a conceptual category referring to human-made objects, often defined by their intended function or design (e.g., "chair," "hammer").

title: Ad Hoc Category
subtitle: a conceptual category formed temporarily for a specific purpose or context, often lacking stable defining features (e.g., "things to take on a picnic," "things that could fall on your head").

title: Goal-Derived Category
subtitle: a conceptual category whose members serve a common goal or satisfy a particular function, regardless of their superficial similarity (e.g., "things to lose weight," "things to escape a fire").

title: Structure of Category
subtitle: the internal organization or representation of a conceptual category.

title: Prototype Theory of Concepts
subtitle: categories are structured around a central, idealized member (the prototype) that best exemplifies the category's features, with graded membership.

title: Exemplar Theory of Concepts
subtitle: categories are represented by a collection of individual stored examples (exemplars) of category members, with new items compared to these stored examples.

title: Theory-Theory of Concepts
subtitle: categories are structured by miniature, implicit theories or explanatory frameworks that guide understanding and classification.

title: Classical View of Concepts
subtitle: categories are defined by a set of necessary and sufficient conditions that all members must possess (less commonly held in modern cognitive science).

title: Belief
subtitle: a mental representation of a proposition or state of affairs accepted by an individual as true or factual.

title: Epistemic Status of Belief
subtitle: classification based on the justification or source of knowledge.

title: Justified Belief
subtitle: a belief held with adequate evidence, reasoning, or support.

title: Empirically Justified Belief
subtitle: based on sensory experience or observation.

title: Logically Justified Belief
subtitle: based on principles of reason or formal deduction.

title: Testimonially Justified Belief
subtitle: based on reliable testimony from others.

title: Unjustified Belief
subtitle: a belief held without adequate evidence or reason.

title: False Belief
subtitle: a belief that does not correspond to reality.

title: True Belief
subtitle: a belief that corresponds to reality.

title: Form of Belief
subtitle: how the belief is held or expressed mentally.

title: Propositional Belief
subtitle: a belief that can be expressed as a declarative statement or proposition (e.g., "It is raining").

title: Dispositional Belief
subtitle: a tendency to act or feel as if a proposition is true, even if not consciously affirmed or considered at every moment.

title: Occurrent Belief
subtitle: a belief that is actively present in conscious thought at a given moment.

title: Content Domain of Belief
subtitle: the subject matter of the belief.

title: Factual Belief
subtitle: belief concerning objective states of affairs (e.g., "Water boils at 100°C").

title: Value Belief
subtitle: belief concerning what is good, bad, right, or wrong (e.g., "Honesty is important").

title: Self-Belief
subtitle: belief about one's own characteristics, abilities, or identity.

title: Social Belief
subtitle: belief about social groups, norms, or societal structures.

title: Centrality of Belief
subtitle: the importance or interconnectedness of a belief within an individual's belief system.

title: Core Belief
subtitle: fundamental, often unconscious, and highly resistant to change; forms the foundation of one's worldview.

title: Peripheral Belief
subtitle: less central, more easily changed beliefs that are often derived from or supported by core beliefs.

title: Desire
subtitle: a mental representation of a desired outcome, state, or object, accompanied by a motivational pull towards its realization.

title: Origin/Nature of Desire
subtitle: classification based on the source or fundamental drive.

title: Basic Desire (Primary/Biological)
subtitle: fundamental, often instinctual desires related to survival and well-being (e.g., for food, water, sleep, safety, procreation).

title: Acquired Desire (Secondary/Learned)
subtitle: desires that are learned or developed through experience, culture, or social interaction (e.g., for money, fame, knowledge).

title: Functional Role of Desire
subtitle: how the desire relates to other goals or outcomes.

title: Instrumental Desire
subtitle: a desire for something as a means to achieve another, more ultimate desire or goal.

title: Terminal Desire (Intrinsic)
subtitle: a desire for something as an end in itself, valued for its own sake.

title: Awareness of Desire
subtitle: the level of conscious access to the desire.

title: Conscious Desire
subtitle: a desire that one is explicitly aware of and can articulate.

title: Unconscious Desire
subtitle: a desire that operates outside of conscious awareness but influences behavior and thought.

title: Semantic Network
subtitle: a mental representation where concepts are nodes and the relationships between them are links, forming a structured knowledge representation.

title: Structural Type of Semantic Network
subtitle: how the network is organized.

title: Hierarchical Semantic Network
subtitle: concepts are organized in a hierarchy, typically using "is-a" (subsumption) and "has-a" (part-whole) links, allowing for property inheritance.

title: Propositional Semantic Network
subtitle: represents knowledge as propositions (statements that can be true or false) where concepts are nodes and relationships form propositions.

title: Processing Model of Semantic Network
subtitle: how information is accessed and processed within the network.

title: Spreading Activation Model
subtitle: activation spreads from an activated node to related nodes, with strength decreasing with distance, explaining priming effects.

title: Self Representation
subtitle: a mental structure representing aspects of one's own personhood

title: Self-Concept
subtitle: overall beliefs about oneself.

title: Personal Identity
subtitle: sense of continuity and uniqueness of self.

title: Social Identity
subtitle: part of self-concept from group membership.

title: Memory Content
subtitle: stored information accessible through memory processes

title: Episodic Memory Content
subtitle: memories of specific events.

title: Semantic Memory Content
subtitle: general knowledge, facts.

title: Procedural Memory Content
subtitle: memories of how to do things.

title: Autobiographical Memory Content
subtitle: memories about one's life.

title: Mental Attribute
subtitle: an inherent quality, property, or characteristic of the mind or mental entities

title: Arousal Dimension
subtitle: a dimension of intensity or energy in mental states

title: Physiological Arousal
subtitle: the physical manifestation of mental arousal, involving bodily systems.

title: Autonomic Arousal
subtitle: arousal mediated by the autonomic nervous system.

title: Sympathetic Arousal
subtitle: 'fight or flight' response, increasing heart rate, blood pressure.

title: Parasympathetic Arousal
subtitle: 'rest and digest' response, decreasing heart rate, promoting relaxation.

title: Cortical Arousal
subtitle: arousal related to brain activity and alertness, measured by EEG.

title: Alpha Wave Dominance
subtitle: characteristic of a relaxed, yet alert state.

title: Beta Wave Dominance
subtitle: characteristic of an alert, active, and focused state.

title: Delta/Theta Wave Dominance
subtitle: characteristic of deep sleep or highly relaxed/meditative states.

title: Subjective Arousal
subtitle: the conscious experience of mental intensity or energy.

title: High Subjective Arousal
subtitle: feelings of being energized, alert, excited, or stressed.

title: Low Subjective Arousal
subtitle: feelings of being calm, relaxed, sluggish, or bored.

title: Valence Dimension
subtitle: a dimension of pleasantness or unpleasantness in mental states

title: Positive Valence
subtitle: the inherent quality of being pleasant, desirable, or rewarding.

title: Hedonic Pleasure
subtitle: direct sensory or emotional pleasure (e.g., taste, warmth, joy).

title: Eudaimonic Well-being Component
subtitle: component of well-being derived from meaning, purpose, and self-realization.

title: Negative Valence
subtitle: the inherent quality of being unpleasant, undesirable, or aversive.

title: Aversive Discomfort
subtitle: direct sensory or emotional pain/discomfort (e.g., physical pain, sadness, fear).

title: Threat-Related Aversion
subtitle: unpleasantness arising from perceived danger or harm.

title: Neutral Valence
subtitle: the absence of significant pleasantness or unpleasantness.

title: Mental Capacity
subtitle: an inherent ability or potential for mental functioning (e.g., capacity for attention, memory capacity) - Potential for performing mental operations.

title: Cognitive Capacity
subtitle: an inherent ability or potential for specific cognitive processes.

title: Attentional Capacity
subtitle: the maximum amount of information or stimuli that can be processed simultaneously or maintained in focus.

title: Sustained Attentional Capacity
subtitle: potential to maintain focus over prolonged periods.

title: Divided Attentional Capacity
subtitle: potential to attend to multiple stimuli or tasks concurrently.

title: Memory Capacity
subtitle: the inherent potential of the memory system to encode, store, and retrieve information.

title: Working Memory Capacity
subtitle: the limited capacity for holding and manipulating information temporarily.

title: Long-Term Memory Capacity
subtitle: the vast, theoretically unlimited capacity for durable storage of information.

title: Processing Speed Capacity
subtitle: the inherent potential for how quickly mental operations can be performed.

title: Reasoning Capacity
subtitle: the inherent potential to draw logical inferences and solve complex problems.

title: Deductive Reasoning Capacity
subtitle: potential to derive specific conclusions from general premises.

title: Inductive Reasoning Capacity
subtitle: potential to derive general principles from specific observations.

title: Problem-Solving Capacity
subtitle: the inherent potential to find solutions to novel or complex situations.

title: Affective Capacity
subtitle: an inherent ability or potential related to emotional experience and regulation.

title: Emotional Experience Capacity
subtitle: the potential range and depth of emotions an individual can experience.

title: Emotional Regulation Capacity
subtitle: the potential to manage and adjust one's emotional responses.

title: Volitional Capacity
subtitle: an inherent ability or potential related to will, motivation, and goal-directed action.

title: Self-Control Capacity
subtitle: the potential to resist impulses and pursue long-term goals.

title: Motivational Capacity
subtitle: the inherent potential to generate and sustain goal-directed energy.

title: Mental Structure/Subsystem
subtitle: a hypothesized enduring division or component of the mind, often with distinct functions or properties.

title: Levels of Consciousness (Topographical Model)
subtitle: hypothesized layers of mental accessibility.

title: Conscious Mind
subtitle: the part of the mind that holds current awareness and direct experience.

title: Active Awareness
subtitle: that which is currently in focal attention.

title: Peripheral Awareness
subtitle: that which is currently registered but not in focal attention.

title: Preconscious Mind
subtitle: the part of the mind containing information that is not currently in awareness but can be readily retrieved.

title: Accessible Memories
subtitle: non-repressed memories that can be brought to conscious awareness.

title: Latent Knowledge
subtitle: knowledge not currently used but retrievable for problem-solving or response.

title: Unconscious Mind (Topographical)
subtitle: the part of the mind containing thoughts, memories, and desires of which one is not aware but which can influence behavior.

title: Repressed Content
subtitle: thoughts or memories actively kept out of conscious awareness due to psychological defense mechanisms.

title: Automatic Processes
subtitle: cognitive or behavioral operations that occur without conscious awareness or effort.

title: Structural Components of Psyche (Freudian Model)
subtitle: hypothesized functional divisions of the personality.

title: Id
subtitle: the primitive, instinctual, and pleasure-seeking component of the personality, operating entirely unconsciously, driven by the pleasure principle.

title: Libido (Id Component)
subtitle: the psychic energy or drive associated with life instincts, including sexual and pleasure-seeking urges.

title: Thanatos (Id Component)
subtitle: the psychic energy or drive associated with death instincts, including aggression and destructive urges.

title: Ego
subtitle: the largely conscious, rational component of the personality that mediates between the demands of the id, the superego, and reality, operating by the reality principle.

title: Executive Function (Ego Role)
subtitle: the planning, decision-making, and self-regulation capacities of the ego.

title: Defense Mechanism (Ego Role)
subtitle: unconscious strategies used by the ego to protect itself from anxiety or unpleasant thoughts.

title: Superego
subtitle: the internalized moral component of the personality, representing ideals and societal standards, often operating unconsciously.

title: Conscience (Superego Component)
subtitle: the part of the superego that punishes behavior that violates moral standards, leading to guilt.

title: Ego Ideal (Superego Component)
subtitle: the part of the superego that represents ideal standards of behavior, leading to feelings of pride when achieved.

title: Archetypes (Jungian Model)
subtitle: universal, archaic patterns and images that derive from the collective unconscious and are the psychic counterpart of instinct.

title: Persona (Archetype)
subtitle: the social mask or role an individual presents to the world, often for public acceptance.

title: Social Role Persona
subtitle: the specific mask adopted for a particular social context (e.g., professional, student).

title: Ideal Self Persona
subtitle: the persona striving to meet societal expectations of perfection.

title: Shadow (Archetype)
subtitle: the unconscious aspect of the personality that the conscious ego does not identify with, often containing undesirable or repressed qualities.

title: Personal Shadow
subtitle: repressed aspects stemming from individual experience.

title: Collective Shadow
subtitle: universally denied or repressed aspects of humanity.

title: Anima/Animus (Archetype)
subtitle: the unconscious feminine image in a man (Anima) / masculine image in a woman (Animus), representing the contrasexual soul image.

title: Anima (Male Psyche)
subtitle: the feminine principle in men.

title: Animus (Female Psyche)
subtitle: the masculine principle in women.

title: Self (Jungian Archetype)
subtitle: the central archetype, representing the unification and totality of consciousness and unconsciousness, aiming for individuation.

title: Mandalas (Self Symbol)
subtitle: circular images often symbolizing the unified Self.

title: Wholeness (Self Characteristic)
subtitle: the ultimate aim of individuation, representing the integration of all psychic aspects.

title: Great Mother (Archetype)
subtitle: archetype symbolizing nurturing, fertility, and destructive aspects of the feminine principle.

title: Wise Old Man (Archetype)
subtitle: archetype symbolizing wisdom, guidance, and spiritual authority.

title: Hero (Archetype)
subtitle: archetype symbolizing courage, struggle, and overcoming adversity.

title: Core Self (Non-Psychodynamic Models)
subtitle: concepts representing a fundamental, authentic, and enduring aspect of an individual's identity, distinct from transient thoughts or emotions.

title: Narrative Self
subtitle: the self as constructed and understood through personal stories, life experiences, and the ongoing integration of past, present, and future.

title: Autobiographical Narrative Self
subtitle: the personal story based on episodic memories of one's own life.

title: Social Narrative Self
subtitle: the self-story influenced by social interactions and cultural expectations.

title: Experiential Self (Minimal Self)
subtitle: the self as directly experienced in the present moment, encompassing immediate consciousness and agency, often considered pre-reflective.

title: Embodied Self
subtitle: the sense of self rooted in one's physical body and its sensations.

title: Subjective Point of View
subtitle: the self as the unique perspective from which experiences are perceived.

title: True Self (Humanistic)
subtitle: the authentic, inherent self, often believed to be discovered through self-actualization, distinct from societal or imposed identities.

title: Actualizing Tendency (Component)
subtitle: the innate drive toward growth and fulfillment of one's potential.

title: Organismic Valuing Process (Component)
subtitle: the innate capacity to evaluate experiences in terms of whether they promote or hinder actualization.

title: Cognitive Architecture
subtitle: a comprehensive theory or model of the structure and function of the human mind, often expressed computationally, specifying how various cognitive processes interact.

title: General Problem Solver (GPS) Architecture
subtitle: an early AI cognitive architecture aiming to simulate human problem-solving through means-ends analysis.

title: Production Rule System (GPS Component)
subtitle: "if-then" rules representing knowledge and actions.

title: Working Memory (GPS Component)
subtitle: temporary storage for current problem state.

title: ACT-R Architecture (Adaptive Control of Thought—Rational)
subtitle: a cognitive architecture that models human cognition by integrating symbolic and sub-symbolic processing, based on modular components.

title: Declarative Memory Module (ACT-R)
subtitle: stores factual and episodic knowledge as "chunks."

title: Procedural Memory Module (ACT-R)
subtitle: stores knowledge about how to do things as production rules.

title: Working Memory Buffers (ACT-R)
subtitle: temporary holding places for information from other modules.

title: SOAR Architecture (State Operator And Result)
subtitle: a cognitive architecture based on universal subgoaling and chunking to model intelligent behavior.

title: Long-Term Memory (SOAR)
subtitle: includes procedural and declarative knowledge.

title: Decision Cycle (SOAR)
subtitle: the fundamental process by which SOAR operates, involving elaboration, proposal, deliberation, and application.

title: Enduring Personality Structure (Trait Models)
subtitle: stable, measurable predispositions that constitute the fundamental building blocks of an individual's personality, theorized as internal structures.

title: Big Five Personality Factors (OCEAN)
subtitle: a widely accepted model proposing five broad dimensions of personality.

title: Openness to Experience (Factor)
subtitle: characterized by imagination, intellectual curiosity, and aesthetic sensitivity.

title: Conscientiousness (Factor)
subtitle: characterized by organization, self-discipline, and responsibility.

title: Extraversion (Factor)
subtitle: characterized by sociability, assertiveness, and energetic behavior.

title: Agreeableness (Factor)
subtitle: characterized by compassion, cooperativeness, and trustworthiness.

title: Neuroticism (Factor)
subtitle: characterized by emotional instability, anxiety, and negative affect.

title: Eysenck's PEN Model
subtitle: a trait theory proposing three superfactors of personality.

title: Psychoticism (Factor)
subtitle: characterized by aggression, impulsivity, and non-conformity.

title: Extraversion (Factor)
subtitle: characterized by sociability and outgoingness.

title: Neuroticism (Factor)
subtitle: characterized by emotional instability and anxiety.

title: Temperament Factors
subtitle: innate, biologically based individual differences in behavioral style and emotional reactivity, appearing early in life.

title: Activity Level (Temperament)
subtitle: refers to a person's general level of motor activity.

title: Emotionality (Temperament)
subtitle: refers to the intensity of emotional reactions.

title: Sociability (Temperament)
subtitle: refers to a person's tendency to affiliate with others.

title: Motivational Drive Systems
subtitle: hypothesized internal structures or processes that generate and direct goal-oriented behavior, often rooted in biological or psychological needs.

title: Behavioral Activation System (BAS)
subtitle: a hypothesized system regulating motivation to approach rewards and engage in goal-directed behavior.

title: Drive (BAS Component)
subtitle: the impulse to pursue desired goals.

title: Reward Responsiveness (BAS Component)
subtitle: sensitivity to positive outcomes and incentives.

title: Behavioral Inhibition System (BIS)
subtitle: a hypothesized system regulating motivation to avoid punishments and inhibit behavior in the face of conflict or threat.

title: Fear (BIS Component)
subtitle: the response to conditioned aversive stimuli.

title: Anxiety (BIS Component)
subtitle: the response to potential threats or uncertainty.

title: Homeostatic Regulation System
subtitle: internal systems that maintain physiological equilibrium (e.g., hunger, thirst drives).

title: Thirst Drive System
subtitle: the internal mechanism prompting water intake.

title: Hunger Drive System
subtitle: the internal mechanism prompting food intake.

title: Memory Systems (Structural)
subtitle: distinct, functionally specialized components of the memory apparatus within the mind.

title: Sensory Memory System
subtitle: very brief storage for incoming sensory information.

title: Iconic Memory
subtitle: visual sensory memory.

title: Echoic Memory
subtitle: auditory sensory memory.

title: Working Memory System
subtitle: a limited-capacity system for temporarily holding and manipulating information during complex cognitive tasks.

title: Phonological Loop
subtitle: a component for processing and temporarily storing auditory and verbal information.

title: Visuospatial Sketchpad
subtitle: a component for processing and temporarily storing visual and spatial information.

title: Central Executive
subtitle: an attentional control system that supervises and coordinates the activity of the phonological loop and visuospatial sketchpad.

title: Long-Term Memory System
subtitle: a vast, relatively permanent storage system for information.

title: Declarative Memory System (Explicit Memory)
subtitle: memory for facts and events that can be consciously recalled.

title: Episodic Memory System
subtitle: memory for specific personal experiences and events with contextual details.

title: Semantic Memory System
subtitle: memory for general world knowledge, facts, concepts, and language meaning.

title: Non-Declarative Memory System (Implicit Memory)
subtitle: memory for skills, habits, and other forms of learning that are not consciously recalled.

title: Procedural Memory System
subtitle: memory for motor skills and habits (e.g., riding a bike).

title: Priming System
subtitle: the unconscious influence of previous exposure to a stimulus on subsequent responses.

title: Mental Mechanism
subtitle: an underlying functional system or structure hypothesized to subserve mental processes

title: Behavioral Activation System
subtitle: a hypothesized system regulating motivation to approach rewards

title: Behavioral Avoidance System
subtitle: a hypothesized system regulating motivation to avoid punishments

title: Mental Phenomenon
subtitle: a discrete event, occurrence, or subjective experience in the mind that is not primarily defined as a state or ongoing process

title: Insight Experience
subtitle: a sudden realization or understanding

title: Mental Condition
subtitle: a pattern of mental functioning considered atypical, impaired, or pathological

title: Mental Disorder
subtitle: a clinically recognized pattern of symptoms affecting mental functioning

title: Anxiety Disorder
subtitle: characterized by excessive worry or fear.

title: Major Depressive Disorder
subtitle: characterized by persistent sadness or loss of interest.

title: Bipolar Disorder
subtitle: characterized by mood swings between depression and mania.

title: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder
subtitle: develops after experiencing a traumatic event.

title: Social
subtitle: The domain encompassing collective entities, structures, processes, and forms arising from the interaction of conscious agents

title: Social Entity
subtitle: A unit or agentive grouping within the social domain, characterized by a degree of internal coherence, boundary, and capacity for collective reference or action.

title: Dyad
