subtitle: A social entity consisting of exactly two interacting individuals.

title: Romantic Dyad
subtitle: A dyad based on a romantic or marital relationship.

title: Friendship Dyad
subtitle: A dyad based on a bond of mutual affection and companionship.

title: Professional Dyad
subtitle: A dyad formed for work-related purposes or within a professional context.

title: Mentor-Mentee Dyad
subtitle: A professional dyad where one individual guides another.

title: Collaborative Pair (Professional)
subtitle: A professional dyad working jointly on a task.

title: Kinship Dyad
subtitle: A dyad based on family ties (blood, marriage, or adoption).

title: Spousal Dyad
subtitle: (overlaps with Romantic Dyad, but emphasizes legal/kinship aspect)

title: Adversarial Dyad
subtitle: A dyad characterized by conflict or direct opposition between the two individuals.

title: Small Group
subtitle: A social entity composed of a limited number of individuals (typically 3 to about 20) who interact regularly, share common goals or identity, and perceive themselves as a group.

title: Family Unit
subtitle: A small group based on kinship ties, often cohabiting and sharing emotional and material resources.

title: Nuclear Family Unit
subtitle: A family unit typically comprising two parents and their dependent children.

title: Extended Family Unit (Cohabiting)
subtitle: A family unit that includes relatives beyond the nuclear family living together or in close proximity and functioning as a single household unit.

title: Peer Group
subtitle: A small group of individuals sharing similar age, social status, background, or interests.

title: Professional Peer Group
subtitle: (e.g., a small group of colleagues at the same level)

title: Task Group / Work Team
subtitle: A small group formed specifically to accomplish a defined task or project.

title: Jury
subtitle: (as a small task group)

title: Support Group
subtitle: A small group whose members provide mutual aid, emotional comfort, and resources for shared challenges or experiences.

title: Clique
subtitle: A small, often exclusive, group of individuals who interact frequently and share strong common interests, sometimes exhibiting strong in-group loyalty.

title: Focus Group (Research)
subtitle: A small group of individuals assembled to participate in a guided discussion for qualitative research purposes.

title: Social Club (Small Scale)
subtitle: A small group organized around shared leisure activities or social interests.

title: Community
subtitle: A social entity comprising a group of people with a shared identity, interests, values, or geographic location, who interact and often share a sense of belonging or mutual interdependence.

title: Geographic Community
subtitle: A community defined by shared physical locality and the social interactions within it.

title: Neighborhood Community
subtitle: A community within a specific residential area of a town or city.

title: Village Community
subtitle: A small, often rural, geographic community.

title: Town Community
subtitle: A geographic community larger than a village but smaller than a city.

title: Community of Interest
subtitle: A community formed around a shared passion, hobby, concern, or intellectual pursuit, not necessarily tied to geography.

title: Hobbyist Community
subtitle: (e.g., gaming community, gardening club members)

title: Activist Community
subtitle: (e.g., a group of environmental activists sharing a common goal)

title: Fan Community / Fandom
subtitle: A community built around shared enthusiasm for a particular cultural phenomenon (e.g., a musician, TV series, book).

title: Community of Practice
subtitle: A community of people who share a concern or a passion for something they do and learn how to do it better as they interact regularly.

title: Online Community / Virtual Community
subtitle: A community whose members primarily interact via digital communication media, often transcending geographical boundaries.

title: Intentional Community
subtitle: A planned residential community whose members share explicit common social, economic, or ecological values and goals. (e.g., cohousing, ecovillage, commune)

title: Ethnic Community
subtitle: A community based on shared ethnicity, cultural heritage, traditions, and often language.

title: Religious Congregation / Faith Community
subtitle: A community of individuals sharing common religious beliefs and practices, often gathering for worship and mutual support.

title: Professional Community (Broad)
subtitle: A community of individuals in the same profession or field, sharing knowledge, standards, and experience (can be broader than a single Community of Practice).

title: Diaspora Community
subtitle: A community of people from a common homeland who are dispersed or scattered in other places, maintaining a sense of connection to their origin.

title: Formal Organization
subtitle: A social entity deliberately constructed and structured to achieve specific goals, characterized by explicit rules, roles, and a hierarchy of authority.

title: Governmental Organization
subtitle: An organization that is part of the structure of a state or public administration.

title: Legislative Body
subtitle: (e.g., Parliament, Congress, City Council)

title: Executive Agency / Department
subtitle: (e.g., Ministry of Health, Environmental Protection Agency)

title: Judicial Body / Court System
subtitle: (as an organizational entity, e.g., Supreme Court, District Court)

title: Intergovernmental Organization (IGO)
subtitle: An organization composed primarily of sovereign states. (e.g., United Nations, World Trade Organization, European Union)

title: Regulatory Agency
subtitle: A governmental organization responsible for setting and enforcing standards and regulations.

title: Public Service Broadcaster
subtitle: A state-funded or publicly owned media organization.

title: Non-Governmental Organization (NGO) / Non-Profit Organization (NPO)
subtitle: An organization that operates independently of government, typically for social, charitable, or advocacy purposes, not primarily for profit.

title: Charitable Organization
subtitle: (focused on philanthropy and social well-being)

title: Advocacy Organization
subtitle: (focused on influencing public policy or opinion)

title: Service Delivery Organization
subtitle: (Non-Profit) (focused on providing specific services like healthcare or education)

title: Foundation (Grant-Making)
subtitle: A non-profit organization that supports other organizations or individuals through grants.

title: Think Tank
subtitle: An organization that conducts research and advocacy on policy issues.

title: Business Enterprise / For-Profit Organization
subtitle: An organization primarily aiming to generate profit for its owners.

title: Partnership
subtitle: (Business)

title: Multinational Corporation
subtitle: (MNC)

title: Small and Medium-sized Enterprise
subtitle: (SME) (as a corporate form)

title: Cooperative (Business)
subtitle: A business owned and operated by and for its members.

title: State-Owned Enterprise (SOE) (Commercial)
subtitle: A business enterprise owned by the state but operating on a commercial basis.

title: Social Enterprise (For-Profit Structure)
subtitle: A for-profit business with explicit social objectives as a core part of its mission.

title: Educational Institution
subtitle: A formal organization dedicated to education and learning.

title: Research Institute
subtitle: (Affiliated with Educational Institution)

title: Healthcare Organization
subtitle: A formal organization providing medical or health-related services.

title: Religious Organization (Institutional)
subtitle: A formal, structured organization dedicated to religious worship, administration, propagation, or service. (e.g., a specific church denomination, a diocese, a religious order, a missionary society).

title: Political Organization
subtitle: A formal organization involved in political processes or governance.

title: Military Organization
subtitle: A formal organization authorized by a state (or other recognized authority) to use force, particularly lethal force, in defense or pursuit of its interests.

title: Cultural Organization
subtitle: A formal organization focused on creating, preserving, exhibiting, or promoting cultural works or heritage.

title: Library
subtitle: (as an organization)

title: Performing Arts Company
subtitle: (e.g., orchestra, theater company, dance troupe)

title: Archive
subtitle: (as an organization)

title: Professional Association / Body
subtitle: A formal organization of professionals in a specific field, often for mutual benefit, development, and self-regulation.

title: Labor Union / Trade Union
subtitle: A formal organization of workers formed to protect and advance their collective interests regarding wages, benefits, and working conditions.

title: Financial Institution
subtitle: A formal organization dealing with financial and monetary transactions. (e.g., Bank, Insurance Company, Investment Firm, Stock Exchange).

title: Media Organization
subtitle: A formal organization involved in producing and distributing news, entertainment, or other information to a mass audience. (e.g., Newspaper Publisher, Broadcasting Network, Film Studio, Publishing House).

title: Research Organization (Independent)
subtitle: A formal organization primarily dedicated to conducting research, not necessarily affiliated with a university.

title: Social Network Entity (Relational Structure)
subtitle: A social entity defined by a specific set of conscious agents (nodes) and the pattern of their interrelationships (ties), considered as a bounded collective unit.

title: Personal Network Entity
subtitle: The set of direct and indirect social connections surrounding a focal individual, considered as a collective unit.

title: Organizational Communication Network Entity
subtitle: The pattern of communication relationships among members within a formal organization, viewed as a distinct entity.

title: Inter-Organizational Network Entity
subtitle: The pattern of relationships connecting multiple formal organizations, considered as a collective unit. (e.g., a strategic alliance network, a supply chain network).

title: Online Social Platform User Network Entity
subtitle: The entire collection of users and their declared connections on a specific online social platform, considered as a single, bounded social entity (distinct from the platform technology itself).

title: Co-authorship Network Entity
subtitle: The collection of researchers (agents) and their co-authorship links (relationships), representing a collaborative intellectual structure.

title: Elite Network Entity
subtitle: A network entity composed of individuals holding prominent positions of power or influence within or across societal sectors.

title: Crowd
subtitle: A temporary, relatively unstructured gathering of a large number of individuals in close physical proximity, often sharing a common focus of attention but typically lacking the cohesion of more organized groups.

title: Casual Crowd
subtitle: A crowd that comes together spontaneously with loose organization and little sustained interaction (e.g., people on a busy street, shoppers in a mall at a given moment).

title: Conventional Crowd
subtitle: A crowd that gathers for a scheduled event and shares a common focus, with behavior governed by established norms (e.g., audience at a concert, attendees at a sporting event).

title: Expressive Crowd
subtitle: A crowd that forms to express an emotion or release tension, often at events like rallies, concerts, or celebrations (e.g., a New Year's Eve crowd, a sports crowd celebrating).

title: Acting Crowd
subtitle: A crowd that engages in overt, often collective, action, which can be volatile and emotionally charged (e.g., a mob, a riot, a panic-stricken crowd fleeing danger).

title: Protest Crowd / Demonstration Group
subtitle: A crowd gathered to publicly express objection or support for a cause, policy, or event.

title: Population Segment / Demographic Group
subtitle: A social entity consisting of a collection of individuals within a larger population, defined by shared demographic, social, or statistical characteristics, and often treated as a distinct unit for social analysis, policy, or address.

title: Age Cohort
subtitle: (e.g., Generation Z, Baby Boomers, Senior Citizens as a demographic group).

title: Gender-Defined Group
subtitle: (as a social category, e.g., women as a demographic in workforce studies).

title: Socioeconomic Class Segment
subtitle: (e.g., the population segment identified as 'upper-middle class' in a survey).

title: Electorate / Voter Segment
subtitle: (e.g., registered voters in a district, a segment of undecided voters).

title: Consumer Segment / Market Segment
subtitle: (e.g., early adopters of technology, luxury goods consumers).

title: Audience Segment
subtitle: (e.g., prime-time television viewers, readers of a specific genre).

title: Ethnic or Racial Demographic Group
subtitle: (as defined for statistical or social analysis purposes).

title: Society
subtitle: A large-scale, enduring, and relatively self-sufficient social entity comprising individuals and groups interconnected through a complex web of relationships, sharing a common culture, and typically occupying a defined territory and organized under a common political and economic system.

title: Nation-State Society
subtitle: a society coterminous with the territory and government of a sovereign state.

title: City-State Society
subtitle: a Nation-State Society organized around a single dominant urban centre and its immediate hinterland.

title: Caral
subtitle: the principal urban polity of the Norte Chico civilization in coastal Peru, noted for its monumental plazas and centralized authority (c. 3500–3000 BCE).

title: Ebla
subtitle: a powerful city-state in northwestern Syria with a palace bureaucracy, extensive trade networks, and its own cuneiform archive (c. 2500–2250 BCE).

title: Mari
subtitle: an Euphrates-river city-state famed for its royal palace archives, diplomatic correspondence, and centralized governance (c. 2900–1759 BCE).

title: Teotihuacan
subtitle: the dominant Mesoamerican city-state in the Valley of Mexico, noted for its pyramidal architecture and urban planning (c. 100–750 CE).

title: Capua
subtitle: an independent Italic city-state in Campania, prominent in Magna Graecia interactions and later allied with Rome (c. 9th–3rd centuries BCE).

title: Cumae
subtitle: a Greek colony and Italic city-state in Campania, noted for its Sibylline sanctuary and trade (c. 750–274 BCE).

title: Praeneste
subtitle: a Latin city-state in Latium, famed for the Sanctuary of Fortuna and its contests with Rome (c. 7th–1st centuries BCE).

title: Saguntum
subtitle: the Iberian city allied with Rome, whose siege precipitated the Second Punic War (c. 6th century BCE–219 BCE).

title: Greek Polis
subtitle: the characteristic city-state of ancient Greece.

title: Athens
subtitle: the polis renowned for democracy, philosophy, and maritime power during the Archaic and Classical periods (c. 800–322 BCE).

title: Sparta
subtitle: the militaristic polis in the Peloponnese, noted for its dual kingship and warrior society (c. 900–192 BCE).

title: Corinth
subtitle: major commercial and naval centre on the Isthmus, host of the Isthmian Games (c. 900–146 BCE).

title: Thebes
subtitle: leading city of Boeotia, defeated Sparta at Leuctra and briefly hegemonized Greece (c. 715–338 BCE).

title: Argos
subtitle: one of the oldest Peloponnesian states, noted for its rivalry with Sparta (c. 700–146 BCE).

title: Miletus
subtitle: Ionian polis famed for early Greek philosophy (Thales) and maritime trade (c. 1000–494 BCE).

title: Ephesus
subtitle: Ionian city renowned for the Temple of Artemis and as a major port (c. 1000 BCE–395 CE).

title: Megara
subtitle: strategic polis between Attica and the Peloponnese, founded the colony Byzantion (c. 750–146 BCE).

title: Rhodes
subtitle: Dorian island‐polis, famed for the Colossus and as a Hellenistic naval power (c. 408 BCE–42 CE).

title: Syracuse
subtitle: Greek colony in Sicily under the Tyrants and later the Deinomenids, rival of Carthage (c. 734–212 BCE).

title: Byzantion
subtitle: the Megarian colony on the Bosporus, later Constantinople, a major Hellenic, Roman and Byzantine centre (c. 657 BCE–1453 CE).

title: Massalia
subtitle: the Phocaean colony on the southern Gaul coast, noted for trade and cultural exchange (c. 600 BCE–49 BCE).

title: Cyrene
subtitle: the Greek colony in Cyrenaica, a centre of Hellenistic philosophy and medicine (c. 631 BCE–96 BCE).

title: Tyre
subtitle: a Phoenician maritime trade society on the Levantine coast, famed for purple dye, shipbuilding, and colonization (c. 1200–538 BCE).

title: Sidon
subtitle: the Phoenician city-state in the Levant, noted for purple dye and maritime commerce (c. 3000–550 BCE).

title: Byblos
subtitle: the ancient Levantine city-state, early adopter of alphabetic script and trade (c. 5000–332 BCE).

title: Arwad
subtitle: the island city-state off Syria, important Phoenician naval station (c. 1300 BCE–64 BCE).

title: Utica
subtitle: the Phoenician colony on North Africa’s coast, early rival to Carthage (c. 1101–146 BCE).

title: Gadir (Gades)
subtitle: the Phoenician colony on the Iberian Atlantic coast, one of the oldest Western Mediterranean settlements (c. 1100–206 BCE).

title: Veii
subtitle: an Etruscan city-state north of Rome, rival of early Roman monarchy and Republic (c. 8th–4th centuries BCE; destroyed 396 BCE).

title: Tarquinia
subtitle: a major Etruscan city-state on the Tyrrhenian coast, noted for its painted tombs and maritime trade (c. 8th–3rd centuries BCE).

title: Caere (Cerveteri)
subtitle: an Etruscan city-state in southern Etruria, famed for its tumulus necropolises and trade networks (c. 9th–3rd centuries BCE).

title: Vulci
subtitle: an Etruscan city-state in southern Etruria, noted for its wealth, art, and iron-smelting (c. 8th–3rd centuries BCE).

title: Volsinii (Orvieto)
subtitle: an Etruscan city-state in central Italy, renowned for its bronze industry; destroyed by Rome in 264 BCE (c. 7th–3rd centuries BCE).

title: Populonia
subtitle: the principal Etruscan port and centre of iron smelting on the Tyrrhenian coast (c. 8th–3rd centuries BCE).

title: Felsina (Bologna)
subtitle: an Etruscan city-state in northern Italy, precursor to the Roman colony Bononia (c. 6th–3rd centuries BCE).

title: Harappa
subtitle: a major urban polity of the Indus Valley Civilization, characterized by grid-plan cities, standardized weights, and a centralized administration (c. 2600–1900 BCE).

title: Mohenjo-daro
subtitle: the principal city-state of the Mature Harappan phase, renowned for its advanced civic planning, drainage systems, and state authority (c. 2500–1900 BCE).

title: Eridu
subtitle: the earliest known city-state in southern Mesopotamia with centralized temple authority (c. 4000 BCE).

title: Uruk
subtitle: the first large-scale urban state in Sumer, noted for its administrative bureaucracy and monumental construction (c. 4000–3100 BCE).

title: Ur
subtitle: a major Sumerian city-state on the Persian Gulf coast, centered on a ziggurat and a temple economy (c. 2600–1800 BCE).

title: Kish
subtitle: an early northern Mesopotamian city-state famed for its dynastic kingship and political preeminence in Sumer (c. 3500 BCE).

title: Lagash
subtitle: a Sumerian city-state that achieved significant political autonomy and artistic patronage in the late 4th millennium BCE.

title: Susa
subtitle: an early Elamite city-state in southwestern Iran, characterized by centralized governance and temple complexes (c. 4000–3000 BCE).

title: Knossos
subtitle: the Minoan palace-city on Crete, early Bronze Age centre of administration and ritual (c. 1900–1400 BCE).

title: Maya City-State Society
subtitle: Classic Maya polities (c. 400 BCE–900 CE).

title: Tikal
subtitle: the great Petén Basin polity with towering temples, stelae, and a powerful dynasty (c. 200–900 CE)

title: Calakmul
subtitle: the “Snake Kingdom,” rival of Tikal, famed for its twin pyramids and far-flung alliances (c. 500–850 CE)

title: Palenque
subtitle: the Chiapas city-state celebrated for its intricate stucco-decorated palaces and the reign of Kʼinich Janaabʼ Pakal (c. 226 BCE–799 CE)

title: Copán
subtitle: the Honduran polity known for its Hieroglyphic Stairway, sculpted altars, and royal tombs (c. 400–800 CE)

title: Caracol
subtitle: major Belize site with dynastic stelae and sprawling causeways (c. 550–859 CE)

title: Yaxchilán
subtitle: Usumacinta-river polity renowned for sculpted lintels and King Itzamnaaj Bʼalam II (c. 200–900 CE)

title: Uxmal
subtitle: Puuc-region city noted for the Governor’s Palace and Circle of a Thousand Columns (c. 600–1000 CE)

title: Chichén Itzá
subtitle: Yucatán capital famous for the Temple of Kukulcán and mixed architectural styles (c. 600–1200 CE)

title: Mayapan
subtitle: postclassic Yucatán federation of Itza lineages (c. 1200–1440 CE)

title: Cobá
subtitle: northern lowlands site with raised roads (sacbé), large pyramid Nohoch Mul (c. 100–900 CE)

title: Moche
subtitle: coastal Peruvian polity famed for its temples, painted ceramics, irrigation works, and warrior-priest elite (c. 100–800 CE)

title: Tiwanaku
subtitle: highland Bolivian centre governing the Lake Titicaca region, celebrated for its monumental platform mounds and raised-field agriculture (c. 300–1000 CE)

title: Kingdom Society
subtitle: a Nation-State Society ruled by a monarch (hereditary or elective), whose authority is institutionalized through dynastic succession or regulated election among eligible royal lineages; social orders are organized around monarchical authority and court hierarchies.

title: Early Dynastic Period of Egypt
subtitle: the unified kingdom of Upper and Lower Egypt under its first pharaoh, Narmer, establishing centralized state institutions (c. 3100–2686 BCE).

title: Old Kingdom of Egypt
subtitle: a unified Egyptian state under the Third to Sixth Dynasties, noted for its centralized bureaucracy and monumental pyramid construction (c. 2686–2181 BCE).

title: Middle Kingdom of Egypt
subtitle: the reunified Egyptian state under Mentuhotep II, featuring centralized administration and pyramid-building (c. 2055–1650 BCE).

title: Shang Dynasty
subtitle: the earliest historically confirmed Chinese state, characterized by bronze metallurgy, oracle-bone writing, and hereditary kingship (c. 1600–1046 BCE).

title: United Monarchy of Israel
subtitle: the united Hebrew monarchy under Saul, David, and Solomon, centered on Jerusalem and Temple worship (c. 1050–930 BCE).

title: Kingdom of Judah
subtitle: the southern Hebrew kingdom ruled from Jerusalem, continuing Davidic traditions after Israel’s division (c. 930–586 BCE).

title: Merovingian Kingdom of the Franks
subtitle: the early medieval Frankish realm founded by Clovis, establishing dynastic rule over Gaul (c. 481–751 CE).

title: Visigothic Kingdom
subtitle: the Germanic successor state in Iberia and southwestern Gaul, blending Roman administration with Gothic aristocracy (c. 418–721 CE).

title: Ostrogothic Kingdom of Italy
subtitle: the Italian kingdom under Theodoric the Great, maintaining Roman governance under Gothic leadership (c. 493–553 CE).

title: Vandal Kingdom
subtitle: the North African state established by the Vandals, controlling Carthage and Mediterranean piracy (c. 435–534 CE).

title: Kingdom of the Lombards
subtitle: the Germanic realm ruling much of Italy after the Gothic Wars, characterized by duchies and Arian Christianity (c. 568–774 CE).

title: Kingdom of Silla
subtitle: the Korean kingdom that unified the peninsula, fostering Buddhist culture and centralized bureaucracy (c. 57 BCE–935 CE; unification 668 CE).

title: Yamato State
subtitle: the early Japanese state under the Yamato court, establishing imperial lineage and Shinto ritual authority (c. 250–710 CE).

title: Kassite Kingdom of Babylonia
subtitle: the Babylonian dynasty under Kassite kings who preserved Mesopotamian culture under foreign rule (c. 1595–1155 BCE).

title: Kingdom of Mitanni
subtitle: the Hurrian state in northern Mesopotamia and Syria, known for chariot warfare and diplomatic treaties with Egypt (c. 1500–1300 BCE).

title: Kingdom of Lydia
subtitle: the Anatolian kingdom credited with inventing coinage and ruled by Croesus at its height (c. 1200–546 BCE).

title: Kingdom of Aksum
subtitle: the northeastern African empire controlling the Red Sea trade routes, famous for its monumental stelae and coinage (c. 100–940 CE).

title: Kingdom of England (Norman period)
subtitle: a medieval European monarchy under William I and his successors, characterized by feudal consolidation and common law (1066–1154 CE).

title: Kingdom of France (Capetian dynasty)
subtitle: the West Frankish realm under the Capetians, noted for gradual centralization of royal authority (c. 987–1214 CE).

title: Kingdom of Portugal
subtitle: the Atlantic maritime kingdom in western Iberia that pioneered European overseas exploration (c. 1139–1910 CE).

title: Crown of Castile
subtitle: the medieval Iberian monarchy that expanded through the Reconquista and later united with Aragon (c. 1230–1479 CE).

title: Crown of Aragon
subtitle: the Mediterranean monarchy in northeastern Iberia that extended into Sicily and southern Italy (c. 1035–1479 CE).

title: Kingdom of Scotland
subtitle: the northern British kingdom noted for its distinct legal system and monarchy (c. 843–1603 CE).

title: Kingdom of Poland
subtitle: the Central European monarchy under the Piast and Jagiellon dynasties, pivotal in medieval European politics (c. 1025–1795 CE).
