title: Tribal Society
subtitle: A society organized primarily around kinship ties, with social structure based on families, clans, or lineages, often with less centralized political authority than a state.

title: Hunter-Gatherer
subtitle: A tribal society whose primary sustenance comes from foraging for wild plants, hunting animals, and fishing, typically nomadic or semi-nomadic.

title: Apache
subtitle: Historically, many Apache groups were nomadic hunter-gatherers, adapting to diverse environments (c. 1500–Present)

title: Comanche
subtitle: Renowned equestrian hunter-gatherers of the Great Plains (c. 1700–Present)

title: Blackfoot
subtitle: Prominent buffalo hunters of the northern Plains (c. 1700–Present)

title: Crow
subtitle: Plains buffalo hunters and gatherers (c. 1700–Present)

title: Nez Perce
subtitle: Historically hunter-gatherers, salmon fishers, and camas-root gatherers in the Plateau region (c. 1500–Present)

title: Cheyenne
subtitle: Primarily buffalo hunters of the Great Plains (c. 1700–Present)

title: Arapaho
subtitle: Shared many cultural traits with Cheyenne, primarily buffalo hunters (c. 1700–Present)

title: Shoshone
subtitle: Hunter-gatherers primarily of the Great Basin and Plateau regions (c. 1500–Present)

title: Inuit
subtitle: Hunter-gatherers adapted to Arctic environments, primarily hunting marine mammals (c. 1200–Present)

title: Pirahã
subtitle: An indigenous group in the Amazon basin of Brazil, known for their distinct language and hunter-gatherer lifestyle (c. pre-Columbian–Present)

title: Selk'nam
subtitle: Hunter-gatherers of the southernmost tip of South America (c. pre-Columbian–1974)

title: San
subtitle: hunter-gatherers of southern Africa (c. pre-Iron Age–Present)

title: Hadza
subtitle: Tanzanian hunter-gatherers of the Great Rift Valley (c. 10 000 BCE–Present)

title: Mbuti
subtitle: Pygmy hunter-gatherers of the Ituri Forest (c. pre-Iron Age–Present)

title: Aeta
subtitle: Philippines rainforest hunter-gatherers (c. pre-Colonial–Present)

title: Batek
subtitle: Malaysian Peninsular rainforest hunter-gatherers (c. pre-Colonial–Present)

title: Horticultural
subtitle: A tribal society that practices small-scale cultivation of plants, often using simple tools and shifting cultivation, typically more settled than hunter-gatherers.

title: Hopi
subtitle: Well-known for their traditional dryland farming of corn, beans, and squash (c. 1200–Present)

title: Pueblo Tribal Societies
subtitle: Sedentary societies practicing extensive agriculture, including irrigation (c. 750–Present)

title: Cherokee
subtitle: Historically practiced settled agriculture, cultivating maize, beans, and squash (c. 1000–Present)

title: Seminole
subtitle: Practiced horticulture, cultivating corn, beans, and squash, alongside hunting and fishing (c. 1700–Present)

title: Creek
subtitle: Southeastern horticulturalists with complex town structures (c. 1700–Present)

title: Choctaw
subtitle: Southeastern horticulturalists, known for agriculture and mound-building (c. 1200–Present)

title: Chickasaw
subtitle: Southeastern horticulturalists, closely related to Choctaw (c. 1200–Present)

title: Yanomami
subtitle: Indigenous people living in the Amazon rainforest on the border of Venezuela and Brazil, practicing horticulture (c. pre-Columbian–Present)

title: Guarani
subtitle: Indigenous people of Paraguay and parts of neighboring countries, known for their horticulture and forest dwelling (c. pre-Columbian–Present)

title: Tupi
subtitle: Historical indigenous groups of Brazil, many of whom practiced horticulture and lived in settled villages (c. pre-Columbian–Present)

title: Mapuche
subtitle: Indigenous people of south-central Chile and southwestern Argentina, known for traditional horticulture and other subsistence strategies (c. pre-Columbian–Present)

title: Trobriand Islanders
subtitle: Melanesian horticulturalists practicing yam cultivation and fishing (c. pre-Contact–Present)

title: Ifugao
subtitle: Philippine highland rice-terrace horticulturalists (c. 800 CE–Present)

title: Munduruku
subtitle: Central Amazon horticulturalists known for riverine gardens (c. pre-Columbian–Present)

title: Khasi
subtitle: Northeastern Indian hill horticulturalists practicing terrace farming (c. pre-Colonial–Present)

title: Hmong
subtitle: Southeast Asian swidden horticulturalists (c. pre-Colonial–Present)

title: Enga
subtitle: Papua New Guinea highlands horticulturalists (c. pre-Contact–Present)

title: Pastoralist
subtitle: A tribal society that primarily subsists on the rearing of domesticated animals, often involving nomadic or transhumant lifestyles.

title: Navajo Tribal Society (Diné)
subtitle: Primarily known for their sheep and goat herding, integrated after European contact (c. 1700–Present)

title: Aymara
subtitle: Indigenous people of the Andes, known for high-altitude pastoralism (llamas, alpacas) and horticulture (c. pre-Columbian–Present)

title: Maasai
subtitle: Nilotic pastoralists of East Africa, known for cattle herding (c. 1600 CE–Present)

title: Fulani
subtitle: West African pastoralists (Fula), renowned for cattle nomadism (c. 1000 CE–Present)

title: Nenets
subtitle: Siberian reindeer-herding pastoralists (c. 1st millennium CE–Present)

title: Kyrgyz
subtitle: Central Asian nomadic pastoralists herding horses and yaks (c. 6th century CE–Present)

title: Sami
subtitle: Arctic reindeer-herding pastoralists of northern Scandinavia (c. pre-Viking Age–Present)

title: Segmentary
subtitle: A tribal society characterized by a decentralized political structure, where social organization is based on a network of kinship segments (lineages, clans) that unite or divide based on context or need.

title: Sioux
subtitle: Many bands and divisions of the Sioux (e.g., Lakota, Dakota) exhibited segmentary social organization, particularly in earlier periods (c. 1700–Present)

title: Many Amazonian Tribal Societies
subtitle: A general category encompassing numerous groups (e.g., Kayapo, Xingu tribes) that often exhibit segmentary political structures (c. pre-Columbian–Present)

title: Nuer
subtitle: Nilotic segmentary society of South Sudan (c. pre-Colonial–Present)

title: Dinka
subtitle: Nilotic segmentary society of South Sudan (c. pre-Colonial–Present)

title: Somali
subtitle: Horn of Africa segmentary clan society (c. pre-Islamic–Present)

title: Chiefdom
subtitle: A tribal society characterized by a more centralized political authority, often hereditary, and greater social stratification than simpler tribes, typically led by a chief or paramount leader.

title: Kwakiutl Tribal Society (Kwakwaka'wakw)
subtitle: Known for their complex social hierarchy, hereditary chiefs, and elaborate potlatch ceremonies (c. pre-Contact–Present)

title: Haida
subtitle: Pacific Northwest Coast tribal society known for their hierarchical social structure and artistic traditions (c. pre-Contact–Present)

title: Tlingit
subtitle: Pacific Northwest Coast tribal society with a complex clan system and social stratification (c. pre-Contact–Present)

title: Taíno
subtitle: Indigenous people of the Caribbean (including parts of Central/South America), organized into chiefdoms at the time of European contact (c. 1200–1600 CE)

title: Pre-Classic Maya Chiefdoms
subtitle: Early political entities in Mesoamerica that exhibited chiefdom-level organization before the development of city-states (c. 2000 BCE–250 CE)

title: Muisca
subtitle: Indigenous people of the Colombian Andes, who had developed complex chiefdoms before the Spanish conquest (c. 600–1537 CE)

title: Tongan Chiefdoms
subtitle: Polynesian societies with hereditary chiefs pre-dating the Tongan monarchy (c. 10th century CE–1000 CE)

title: Fijian Chiefdoms
subtitle: Melanesian stratified societies organized around hereditary chiefs (c. pre-Contact–1854 CE)

title: Māori Iwi
subtitle: Māori tribal chiefdoms of New Zealand, led by rangatira (c. 13th century CE–Present)

title: Iroquois Confederacy (Haudenosaunee)
subtitle: While a confederacy, its structured political system with councils and shared decision-making exhibits characteristics of a complex tribal society (c. 1570–Present)

title: Powhatan Confederacy
subtitle: Algonquian tribes of Tidewater Virginia united under Wahunsenacawh (c. 1583–1646 CE)

title: Lakota Confederacy
subtitle: alliance of Lakota Sioux bands in the northern Plains (c. 17th century CE–Present)

title: Blackfoot Confederacy
subtitle: Niitsitapi alliance of Siksika, Kainai, and Piikani bands (c. 18th century CE–Present)

title: Massachusetts Bay Colony
subtitle: an early North American English settlement governed by Puritan religious principles and leaders (1629–1691 CE).

title: Historical Societal Formation
subtitle: A distinct type of society identified by its characteristic social, economic, and political structures in a specific historical period (e.g., Feudal Society in medieval Europe, Ancient Athenian Society).

title: Proto-State Society
subtitle: emergent polities with incipient state features (tribute, proto-bureaucracy, urbanizing chiefdoms).

title: Protodynastic Period of Egypt (Dynasty 0)
subtitle: a grouping of Upper Egyptian chiefdoms consolidating centralized rule prior to formal unification (c. 3200–3000 BCE).

title: Scandinavian Chiefdoms
subtitle: petty kingdoms of Viking-Age Denmark, Norway and Sweden (c. 8th–11th c. CE)

title: Kingdom of Denmark
subtitle: (Viking Age)

title: Kingdom of Norway
subtitle: (Viking Age)

title: Kingdom of Sweden
subtitle: (Viking Age)

title: Icelandic Commonwealth
subtitle: free-assembly Norse polity on Iceland (930–1262 CE)

title: Late Uruk Mesopotamia
subtitle: the transitional “proto-state” with temple-bureaucracy and urban precincts (c. 3500–3100 BCE)

title: Social Structure
subtitle: a patterned relationship or arrangement among social entities.

title: Social Network Structure
subtitle: the pattern of ties and connections among agents.

title: Social Stratification System
subtitle: system of ranked arrangements based on status, power, resources.

title: Status Hierarchy
subtitle: a ranking based on prestige or honor.

title: Class System
subtitle: a ranking based on socioeconomic status.

title: Caste System
subtitle: a ranking based on inherited status.

title: Social Status Position
subtitle: a defined position within a social structure or hierarchy.

title: Role Structure
subtitle: patterned set of roles and their relationships within group.

title: Social Construct
subtitle: an established pattern, institution, cultural element, or conceptual unit shaping social reality.

title: Social Institution
subtitle: enduring normative framework governing collective behavior.

title: Family Institution
subtitle: institution related to kinship and reproduction.

title: Economic Institution
subtitle: institution related to production, distribution, consumption.

title: Political Institution
subtitle: institution related to power, governance, authority.

title: Legal Institution
subtitle: institution related to laws and justice.

title: Educational Institution
subtitle: institution related to teaching and learning.

title: Religious Institution
subtitle: institution related to shared beliefs and practices.

title: Social Culture
subtitle: a shared symbolic system and collection of norms, values, and beliefs.

title: Belief System
subtitle: a shared set of convictions about reality.

title: Value System
subtitle: a shared set of principles regarding desirable goals/behaviors.

title: Custom
subtitle: a traditional and widely accepted way of behaving.

title: Symbolic Communication System
subtitle: shared system for conveying meaning through symbols.

title: Social Norm
subtitle: an expected standard of behavior in a group.

title: Social Role
subtitle: an expected pattern of behavior associated with a status/position.

title: Family Role
subtitle: expected behavior within a family unit.

title: Occupational Role
subtitle: expected behavior in a job or profession.

title: Gender Role
subtitle: expected behavior based on gender.

title: Age Role
subtitle: expected behavior based on age.

title: Social Identity
subtitle: an agent's self-concept derived from group membership.

title: Ethnic Identity
subtitle: identity based on shared culture or ancestry.

title: National Identity
subtitle: identity based on citizenship or nationhood.

title: Organizational Identity
subtitle: identity based on membership in organization.

title: Community Identity
subtitle: identity based on membership in a community.

title: Social Process
subtitle: a dynamic sequence of interactions, behaviors, or changes within the social domain.

title: Socialization Process
subtitle: acquiring norms, values, and roles.

title: Enculturation Process
subtitle: acquiring the culture of a specific society.

title: Communication Process
subtitle: exchange of information or meaning between agents.

title: Cooperation Process
subtitle: coordinated effort toward shared goals.

title: Collective Action Process
subtitle: coordinated effort by a group for common objective.

title: Social Movement Process
subtitle: collective action aimed at social change.

title: Competition Process
subtitle: contestation over resources or outcomes.

title: Conflict Process
subtitle: active disagreement or opposition.

title: Persuasion Process
subtitle: influencing beliefs, attitudes, or behavior.

title: Network Evolution Process
subtitle: changes in structure or ties of social network.

title: Innovation Diffusion Process
subtitle: spread of new ideas/practices through social system.

title: Social System
subtitle: an integrated complex of interdependent social entities, structures, processes, and forms.

title: Economic System
subtitle: system for production, distribution, consumption of goods.

title: Market-Oriented Economic System
subtitle: An economic system where decisions regarding investment, production, and distribution are primarily guided by the price signals created by the forces of supply and demand in markets, with varying degrees of private ownership and regulatory oversight.

title: Capitalist Economic System
subtitle: A kind of Market-Oriented Economic System characterized by private ownership of the means of production and their operation for profit, capital accumulation, wage labor, and competitive markets.

title: Laissez-faire Capitalist System
subtitle: A kind of Capitalist Economic System with minimal government intervention in economic affairs, emphasizing free markets and private property rights.

title: Social Market Economy
subtitle: A kind of Capitalist Economic System that combines a free-market capitalist economic system with social policies aimed at fair competition, social welfare, and the common good (e.g., Germany's Soziale Marktwirtschaft).

title: State Capitalist System
subtitle: A kind of Capitalist Economic System where the state plays a significant role as a major economic actor, owning and operating commercial enterprises for profit within a market framework, or heavily directing private capital.

title: Crony Capitalist System
subtitle: A kind of Capitalist Economic System where economic success is dependent on close relationships between business people and government officials, often leading to favoritism in the allocation of legal permits, government grants, tax breaks, or other forms of state intervention.

title: Market Socialist Economic System
subtitle: A kind of Market-Oriented Economic System characterized by social (collective or public) ownership of the means of production, where allocation of resources is primarily achieved through market mechanisms.

title: Command/Planned Economic System
subtitle: An economic system in which decisions regarding production, investment, prices, and incomes are determined centrally by a governmental authority or planning agency, rather than by market forces.

title: State Socialist Command Economic System
subtitle: A kind of Command/Planned Economic System characterized by state ownership of the means of production and comprehensive central planning of economic activity, aiming to directly satisfy societal needs or state objectives.

title: Communist State Economic System (Practical Implementation)
subtitle: A kind of State Socialist Command Economic System as implemented in states governed by communist parties, characterized by near-total state control over the economy, collectivized agriculture, and allocation of resources through centralized plans (e.g., Soviet-type economy).

title: Mixed Economic System
subtitle: An economic system that incorporates elements from more than one economic system, typically blending private and public enterprise, market-based allocation with government intervention, or free markets with social welfare policies.

title: Dirigiste Economic System
subtitle: A kind of Mixed Economic System where the state plays a strong directive role in guiding economic development through strategic intervention, indicative planning, and influencing investment, while still allowing for significant private enterprise and market activity.

title: Nordic Model Economic System
subtitle: A kind of Mixed Economic System characterized by a robust market-based economy, private ownership, and free trade, combined with a comprehensive universal welfare state, high levels of unionization, and collective bargaining.

title: Corporatist Economic System
subtitle: A kind of Mixed Economic System where economic policy is substantially shaped by negotiations and agreements among large, organized interest groups representing business, labor, and sometimes agriculture, often in conjunction with the state.

title: Traditional Economic System
subtitle: An economic system in which economic decisions are based on customs, traditions, beliefs, and historical precedent, often involving subsistence agriculture, hunting/gathering, and limited specialization or trade.

title: Barter Economic System
subtitle: An economic system where goods and services are directly exchanged for other goods and services without the use of money as a medium of exchange.

title: Gift Economic System
subtitle: An economic system where goods and services are given without an explicit agreement for immediate or future reciprocity, often based on social relationships, status, or communal sharing.

title: Feudal Economic System
subtitle: A historical economic system, primarily in medieval Europe, characterized by a decentralized structure based on land ownership (fiefs) held by a nobility, reciprocal obligations between lords and vassals, and labor performed by serfs tied to the land.

title: Mercantilist Economic System
subtitle: A historical economic system, prevalent from the 16th to 18th centuries, characterized by national economic policies aimed at accumulating monetary reserves through a positive balance of trade, often involving protectionism, state-chartered monopolies, and colonial exploitation.

title: Participatory Economic System (Parecon)
subtitle: A proposed theoretical economic system characterized by social ownership of productive assets, participatory worker and consumer councils, remuneration based on effort and sacrifice, balanced job complexes, and participatory planning for allocation.

title: Political System
subtitle: system of government and power distribution.

title: Anarchist System
subtitle: A political system characterized by the absence of a state and coercive authority, advocating for stateless societies based on voluntary associations.

title: Anarcho-Communism
subtitle: (A kind of Anarchist System with communal ownership.)

title: Anarcho-Syndicalism
subtitle: (A kind of Anarchist System emphasizing worker-organized syndicates.)

title: Anarcho-Capitalism
subtitle: (A kind of Anarchist System with private property and free markets.)

title: Mutualist System
subtitle: (A kind of Anarchist System based on mutual exchange and credit.)

title: Anarcho-Pacifist System
subtitle: (A kind of Anarchist System committed to non-violent means.)

title: Authoritarian System
subtitle: A political system characterized by strong central power, limited political freedoms, and the subordination of individual freedoms to the state, lacking constitutional accountability of rulers to the populace.

title: Totalitarian System
subtitle: (A kind of Authoritarian System where the state seeks to control all aspects of public and private life.)

title: Fascist System
subtitle: (A kind of Totalitarian System with specific corporatist, nationalist, and militaristic ideologies.)

title: Democratic System
subtitle: A political system where supreme power is vested in the people and exercised by them directly or indirectly through a system of representation, typically involving free and fair elections.

title: Direct Democracy
subtitle: (A kind of Democratic System where citizens vote directly on policy initiatives.)

title: Representative Democracy
subtitle: (A kind of Democratic System where citizens elect representatives to make decisions.)

title: Liberal Democracy
subtitle: (A kind of Representative Democracy emphasizing individual rights and freedoms under the rule of law.)

title: Monarchical System
subtitle: A political system in which a monarch (e.g., king, queen, emperor) is the head of state, with sovereignty typically vested in that individual.

title: Absolute Monarchy
subtitle: (A kind of Monarchical System where the monarch holds unrestricted political power.)

title: Constitutional Monarchy
subtitle: (A kind of Monarchical System where the monarch's powers are defined and limited by a constitution. Note: This can range from systems where the monarch retains significant power to those where they are largely ceremonial. If ceremonial and power is democratic, it's also a "Democratic System" in practice.)

title: Elective Monarchy
subtitle: (A kind of Monarchical System where the monarch is elected rather than strictly hereditary.)

title: Hereditary Monarchy
subtitle: (A kind of Monarchical System where succession is based on lineage.)

title: Oligarchic System
subtitle: A political system where political power rests with a small, elite segment of society.

title: Aristocracy
subtitle: (A kind of Oligarchic System where rule is by a hereditary nobility or privileged class.)

title: Plutocracy
subtitle: (A kind of Oligarchic System where rule is by the wealthy.)

title: Military Junta
subtitle: (A kind of Oligarchic System where rule is by a committee of military leaders.)

title: Technocracy
subtitle: (A kind of Oligarchic System where rule is by technical experts or the scientific elite.)

title: Gerontocracy
subtitle: (A kind of Oligarchic System where rule is by elders.)

title: Particracy
subtitle: (A kind of Oligarchic System where effective rule is by political parties or party leaderships, rather than individual citizens or broadly elected officials.)

title: Kritarchy / Krytocracy
subtitle: (A kind of Oligarchic System where rule is by judges.)

title: Republic (Structural Form)
subtitle: A political system in which the country is considered a "public matter", not the private concern or property of the rulers, and where offices of state are consequently directly or indirectly elected or appointed rather than inherited. The head of state is typically a president, not a monarch.

title: Parliamentary Republic
subtitle: (A kind of Republic where the executive branch derives its legitimacy from and is accountable to the legislature.)

title: Presidential Republic
subtitle: (A kind of Republic where the executive branch is separate from the legislature, and the president is both head of state and head of government.)

title: Semi-Presidential Republic
subtitle: (A kind of Republic with both a president and a prime minister, with power divided between them.)

title: Islamic Republic
subtitle: (A kind of Republic governed in accordance with Islamic law. This is a hybrid; its primary classification as a Republic is based on its non-monarchical elective structure.)

title: Single-Party Republic
subtitle: (A kind of Republic where a single political party is legally permitted to hold effective power.)

title: Communist Republic
subtitle: (Single-Party) (A kind of Single-Party Republic based on communist ideology.)

title: Theocratic System
subtitle: A political system in which a deity is recognized as the supreme civil ruler, the deity's laws are interpreted by ecclesiastical authorities (priests or other religious figures), or which is otherwise dominated by religious law and leadership.

title: Hierocracy
subtitle: (A kind of Theocratic System with direct government by priests or religious ministers.)

title: Unitary State System
subtitle: A political system where the central government is supreme, and any administrative divisions (sub-national units) exercise only powers that the central government chooses to delegate.

title: Federal State System (Federation)
subtitle: A political system characterized by a union of partially self-governing provinces, states, or other regions under a central (federal) government, with power constitutionally divided between them.

title: Confederal State System (Confederation)
subtitle: A political system where sovereign states delegate certain powers to a central government, yet retain ultimate authority.

title: Feudal System
subtitle: A historical decentralized political, economic, and social system based on reciprocal legal and military obligations among the warrior nobility, revolving around lords, vassals, and fiefs.

title: Tribal Political System / Chiefdom
subtitle: A political system based on kinship ties, often with a chief or council of elders holding authority, common in smaller-scale or pre-state societies.

title: Diarchy
subtitle: A political system of government in which two individuals (diarchs) are joint heads of state.

title: Empire (as a political system form)
subtitle: An extensive group of states or countries under a single supreme authority, typically an emperor or empress, or a dominant state. (The internal governance of an empire can vary, e.g., monarchical, oligarchic).

title: City-State System
subtitle: A political system where an independent or autonomous entity's territory consists of a city and potentially its surrounding territory.

title: Dictatorship (as a distinct form)
subtitle: A political system where a single individual (a dictator) or a small group holds absolute governmental power, typically obtained by force or inheritance within a non-monarchical system, and not subject to popular consent or constitutional limitations.

title: Military Dictatorship
subtitle: (Personalist rule by a military leader, distinct from a Military Junta which is oligarchic)

title: Legal System
subtitle: system of rules enforced by authority.

title: Civil Law System
subtitle: A legal system based on comprehensive, systematically organized, and written statutes and codes that serve as the primary source of law, with judges primarily applying these codes.

title: Romanistic Civil Law System
subtitle: A kind of Civil Law System heavily influenced by Roman Law via the Napoleonic Code and similar codifications (e.g., France, Spain, Italy, Latin American countries).

title: Germanic Civil Law System
subtitle: A kind of Civil Law System characterized by systematic and scholarly codifications influenced by German legal science (e.g., Germany, Austria, Switzerland, Japan, South Korea).

title: Scandinavian Civil Law System
subtitle: A kind of Civil Law System found in Nordic countries, characterized by a less rigidly codified approach, greater emphasis on legislative preparatory materials, and some influence from customary law (e.g., Sweden, Denmark, Norway, Finland, Iceland).

title: Socialist Civil Law System (Post-Soviet/Transitional)
subtitle: A kind of Civil Law System in countries transitioning from former Socialist Law systems, retaining civil code structures but adapting to market economies and new constitutional frameworks.

title: Common Law System
subtitle: A legal system characterized by law developed by judges through decisions of courts (case law or precedent) and similar tribunals, in addition to statutes adopted by legislative bodies.

title: English Common Law System
subtitle: The kind of Common Law System originating in England and forming the basis for many other common law jurisdictions, characterized by the doctrine of parliamentary sovereignty and a particular historical development of writs and equity.

title: American Common Law System
subtitle: A kind of Common Law System as developed in the United States, characterized by constitutional supremacy, judicial review, federal and state jurisdictions, and distinct developments in areas like tort and contract law.

title: Commonwealth Common Law System
subtitle: A kind of Common Law System found in many current and former member states of the Commonwealth of Nations (excluding the UK itself, which is covered by English Common Law, and Canada/Australia if considered distinct enough), sharing historical roots with English law but with local statutory modifications and jurisprudential developments.

title: Religious Law System
subtitle: A legal system where the source of law is religious texts, traditions, and interpretations, governing aspects of public and/or private life.

title: Islamic Legal System (Sharia-based)
subtitle: A kind of Religious Law System derived from the Quran, Sunnah (teachings and practices of Prophet Muhammad), scholarly consensus (Ijma), and analogical reasoning (Qiyas).

title: Jewish Legal System (Halakha-based)
subtitle: A kind of Religious Law System derived from the Torah, Talmud, rabbinic enactments, and customs, governing many aspects of Jewish life.

title: Canon Law System (Christian)
subtitle: A kind of Religious Law System developed by various Christian denominations (e.g., Catholic, Anglican, Orthodox) to govern internal church administration, rights and obligations of members, and religious ceremonies.

title: Hindu Legal System (Classical/Personal Status)
subtitle: A kind of Religious Law System derived from classical Hindu texts like the Dharmashastras, primarily applied historically and in some contemporary contexts to personal status laws for Hindus in certain jurisdictions.

title: Customary Law System
subtitle: A legal system based on the long-established customs, traditions, and practices of a particular community or people, recognized as binding rules of conduct.

title: Indigenous Peoples' Customary Law System
subtitle: A kind of Customary Law System developed and maintained by indigenous communities, often concerning land tenure, resource management, family relations, and traditional dispute resolution.

title: Local Community Customary Law System
subtitle: A kind of Customary Law System specific to a geographically defined local community, governing local practices and interpersonal relations not necessarily tied to a broader indigenous identity.

title: Traditional Maritime Customary Law System
subtitle: A kind of Customary Law System comprising ancient and widely accepted practices among seafarers and maritime communities governing conduct and rights at sea (distinct from codified Law of the Sea).

title: Mixed Legal System
subtitle: A legal system that combines elements from two or more different legal traditions.

title: Common Law-Civil Law Hybrid System
subtitle: A kind of Mixed Legal System integrating significant elements of both Common Law and Civil Law traditions (e.g., Scotland, Louisiana, Quebec, South Africa).

title: Civil Law-Religious Law Hybrid System
subtitle: A kind of Mixed Legal System where Civil Law coexists with and is influenced by Religious Law, particularly in areas of personal status or family law (e.g., many Middle Eastern countries).

title: Common Law-Religious Law Hybrid System
subtitle: A kind of Mixed Legal System integrating elements of Common Law with Religious Law (e.g., some aspects of law in India, Malaysia).

title: Civil Law-Customary Law Hybrid System
subtitle: A kind of Mixed Legal System where codified Civil Law operates alongside recognized systems of Customary Law (e.g., some African nations).

title: Common Law-Customary Law Hybrid System
subtitle: A kind of Mixed Legal System where Common Law operates alongside recognized systems of Customary Law (e.g., some Pacific Island nations, parts of Africa).

title: International Legal System
subtitle: The system of rules, norms, and standards generally accepted in relations between nations and other international subjects, primarily governing interactions between sovereign states.

title: Public International Law System
subtitle: The overarching framework of rules and principles governing the conduct of states and intergovernmental organizations in their relations with one another.

title: International Criminal Legal System
subtitle: A kind of International Legal System comprising substantive laws defining international crimes (e.g., genocide, war crimes) and procedural laws for prosecution by international courts and tribunals (e.g., ICC, ad hoc tribunals).

title: International Human Rights Legal System
subtitle: A kind of International Legal System comprising treaties, customary norms, and institutional mechanisms designed to promote and protect fundamental human rights at the global and regional levels.

title: International Economic Legal System
subtitle: A kind of International Legal System governing international trade, investment, finance, and monetary relations between states and other international actors (e.g., WTO law, bilateral investment treaties).

title: Law of the Sea System
subtitle: A kind of International Legal System, largely codified in UNCLOS, governing states' rights and responsibilities regarding the use of the world's oceans and their resources.

title: Supranational Legal System
subtitle: A legal system where sovereign states delegate certain law-making and judicial powers to an overarching international organization whose laws have direct effect and/or supremacy over national laws in specific areas.

title: European Union Legal System
subtitle: A kind of Supranational Legal System characterized by its own autonomous legal order, with institutions that create laws directly applicable and often supreme within EU member states.

title: Regional Integration Community Legal System (Advanced)
subtitle: A kind of Supranational Legal System developed by a regional bloc of states (other than the EU) that exhibits significant supranational characteristics, such as a court with binding authority over member states and directly applicable community law in certain domains (e.g., potentially the East African Community's Court of Justice in some respects).

title: Feudal Legal System
subtitle: A historical legal system, particularly in medieval Europe, based on reciprocal obligations between lords and vassals, land tenure (fiefs), and a hierarchical social structure, with law often being localized and customary.

title: European Feudal Legal System
subtitle: The kind of Feudal Legal System prevalent in medieval Europe, characterized by manorial justice, vassalage, fiefs, and a complex web of personal and proprietary obligations.

title: Japanese Feudal Legal System (Shogunate Era)
subtitle: The kind of Feudal Legal System existing in Japan, particularly under the Shogunate, characterized by the rule of shoguns and daimyos, a samurai warrior class, and distinct codes of conduct and landholding systems.

title: Health System
subtitle: system for providing healthcare.

title: Education System
subtitle: system for providing education.

title: Transportation System
subtitle: system for moving people or goods.

title: Environmental Governance System
subtitle: system for managing human-environment interaction.

title: Socio-Technical System
subtitle: system integrating social and technical components.

title: Mass Media System
subtitle: system for communication to large audience.

title: Social Media System
subtitle: system for online social interaction.

title: Online Community System
subtitle: system for virtual group interaction.

title: Surveillance System
subtitle: system for monitoring behavior.

title: Algorithmic Governance System
subtitle: system using algorithms for control.

title: Human-Computer Interface System
subtitle: system for human-computer interaction.

title: Social Change
subtitle: a significant transformation in the patterns, structures, or systems of the social domain. (A kind of social concept/transformation in the domain).

title: Revolution
subtitle: a rapid, fundamental, and often violent social change. (A kind of Social Change).

title: Policy Reform
subtitle: intentional change in laws, regulations, or government practices. (A kind of Social Change).

title: Globalization
subtitle: increasing interconnectedness and interdependence across national borders. (A kind of Social Change).

title: Modernization
subtitle: societal transformation associated with industrialization, urbanization, and rationalization. (A kind of Social Change).

title: Social Phenomenon
subtitle: an observable emergent pattern or event resulting from collective interaction among agents

title: Collective Behavior Phenomenon
subtitle: spontaneous, unstructured, and often volatile actions or expressions by a large number of people in response to a common stimulus or situation.

title: Crowd Behavior Phenomenon
subtitle: emergent behaviors (e.g. panic, synchronization) in large gatherings of agents.

title: Mass Hysteria Phenomenon
subtitle: the rapid, uncontrolled spread of collective anxiety or physiological symptoms within a group, often without a clear external cause.

title: Conversion Disorder Epidemic
subtitle: spread of medically unexplained symptoms within a confined group.

title: Collective Delusion
subtitle: rapid spread of a false belief or impression among a group, often without a basis in reality.

title: Collective Panic Phenomenon
subtitle: a rapid, uncontrolled spread of fear and irrational behavior through a group in response to perceived danger.

title: Flight Panic
subtitle: disorganized escape behavior by a group in perceived danger.

title: Scapegoat Panic
subtitle: collective irrational blame directed at a minority group during crisis.

title: Riot Phenomenon
subtitle: a form of civil disorder characterized by a group of people engaging in random or uncontrolled violence and destruction.

title: Mob Behavior
subtitle: a disorderly and aggressive collective behavior by a crowd, often directed towards a specific target.

title: Mass Action Phenomenon
subtitle: concerted or convergent behaviors by a large number of people, often less volatile and more diffuse than crowd behavior.

title: Fad Phenomenon
subtitle: a short-lived, intense, and widely shared enthusiasm for a particular activity, style, or object.

title: Craze Phenomenon
subtitle: a more intense and obsessive, but still short-lived, collective enthusiasm than a fad.

title: Fashion Phenomenon
subtitle: a widespread adoption of a particular style, trend, or custom, characterized by cycles of popularity and obsolescence.

title: Public Opinion Shift
subtitle: a noticeable change in the collective attitudes or beliefs of a significant portion of a population.

title: Social Movement Phenomenon
subtitle: collective action aimed at social change, often with a more organized and sustained nature than other forms of collective behavior.

title: Reform Movement
subtitle: a social movement advocating for gradual changes within existing societal structures.

title: Revolutionary Movement
subtitle: a social movement aiming for radical and fundamental change of existing societal structures.

title: Expressive Movement
subtitle: a social movement focused on changing individuals' behavior or internal states rather than societal structures.

title: Resistance Movement
subtitle: a social movement opposing an existing authority or dominant power.

title: Religious Movement
subtitle: a social movement centered around religious beliefs and practices, often leading to new denominations or sects.

title: Rumor Phenomenon
subtitle: the unverified and informal dissemination of information through a social network.

title: Gossip
subtitle: informal and often evaluative talk about other people's personal affairs.

title: Urban Legend
subtitle: a modern form of folklore consisting of fictional stories circulated as true.

title: Conspiracy Theory Spread
subtitle: the widespread belief in a secret plot by powerful individuals or groups, often lacking credible evidence.

title: Social Influence Phenomenon
subtitle: the effect that the words, actions, or mere presence of other people have on our thoughts, feelings, attitudes, or behavior.

title: Conformity Phenomenon
subtitle: the act of matching attitudes, beliefs, and behaviors to group norms or the actions of others.

title: Informational Conformity
subtitle: adherence to group behavior due to believing others have more accurate information.

title: Normative Conformity
subtitle: adherence to group behavior to gain acceptance or avoid rejection.

title: Ingratiational Conformity
subtitle: conforming to gain favor or approval from others.

title: Obedience Phenomenon
subtitle: changing behavior in response to a direct command from an authority figure.

title: Destructive Obedience
subtitle: obedience to commands that cause harm to others or oneself.

title: Compliance Phenomenon
subtitle: publicly acting in accordance with a request while privately disagreeing.

title: Foot-in-the-Door Phenomenon
subtitle: tendency to comply with a large request after first agreeing to a small, related request.

title: Door-in-the-Face Phenomenon
subtitle: tendency to comply with a smaller, second request after rejecting a large, initial request.

title: Low-Ball Phenomenon
subtitle: strategy where an item or service is offered at a lower price than intended, and then additional costs are added.

title: Persuasion Phenomenon
subtitle: the process of influencing attitudes or behavior through communication or reasoning.

title: Central Route Persuasion
subtitle: persuasion occurring when people focus on the arguments and evidence.

title: Peripheral Route Persuasion
subtitle: persuasion occurring when people are influenced by superficial cues (e.g., attractiveness of source).

title: Social Contagion Phenomenon
subtitle: the spread of emotions, attitudes or behaviors through interpersonal networks.

title: Emotional Contagion (Spread)
subtitle: the rapid spread of emotions from one person to another within a group.

title: Behavioral Contagion (Spread)
subtitle: the rapid spread of specific behaviors or actions within a group.

title: Belief Contagion
subtitle: the spread of beliefs or ideas through a social network.

title: Group Performance Phenomenon
subtitle: observable patterns related to how individuals perform tasks when in a group setting.

title: Social Loafing Phenomenon
subtitle: reduction in individual effort when working in a group compared to working alone.

title: Diffusion of Responsibility (Contributing Factor)
subtitle: a decrease in individual sense of obligation to act when others are present.

title: Sucker Effect (Contributing Factor)
subtitle: reduction of effort by individuals to avoid being the sole contributor when others are loafing.

title: Social Facilitation Phenomenon
subtitle: enhancement of individual performance in the presence of others.

title: Co-action Effect
subtitle: improved performance when others are performing the same task simultaneously.

title: Audience Effect
subtitle: improved performance when watched by an audience.

title: Group Polarization Phenomenon
subtitle: the tendency for groups to make decisions that are more extreme than the initial inclinations of their members.

title: Groupthink Phenomenon
subtitle: a cognitive bias in cohesive groups leading to irrational or dysfunctional decision‐making.

title: Collective Intelligence Phenomenon
subtitle: superior problem‐solving or decision‐making emerging from group collaboration.

title: Wisdom of Crowds
subtitle: the aggregation of diverse individual judgments yields a collective judgment that is often better than any individual's.

title: Distributed Cognition (Group)
subtitle: cognitive processes are distributed across individuals, tools, and the environment in a collective system.

title: Social Inhibition Phenomenon
subtitle: decreased individual performance in the presence of others due to increased arousal or evaluation apprehension.

title: Social Systemic Phenomenon
subtitle: emergent patterns related to the structure, dynamics, and self-organization of social systems.

title: Network Phenomenon
subtitle: patterns related to the connections and relationships within social networks.

title: Small-World Phenomenon
subtitle: the empirical property that most agents are connected by surprisingly short path lengths in large networks.

title: Six Degrees of Separation Concept
subtitle: the idea that all people are on average six social connections away from each other.

title: High Clustering Coefficient
subtitle: a property of small-world networks where nodes tend to form tightly knit groups.

title: Homophily Phenomenon
subtitle: the tendency of agents to form ties with similar others.

title: Status Homophily
subtitle: tendency to connect with others of similar social status.

title: Value Homophily
subtitle: tendency to connect with others sharing similar beliefs and values.

title: Assortativity (Network Property)
subtitle: the preference for network nodes to attach to others that are similar in some way.

title: Centrality (Network Property)
subtitle: measures quantifying the importance or influence of a node within a network.

title: Social Dilemma Phenomenon
subtitle: a situation in which a choice made by an individual or group, while appearing rational in the short term, leads to a sub-optimal outcome for all involved in the long term.

title: Prisoner's Dilemma (Social Dilemma)
subtitle: a classic game theory scenario illustrating why two rational individuals might not cooperate, even if it appears to be in their best interest to do so.

title: Public Goods Game
subtitle: an experimental game that explores the decision-making around contributing to a common good.

title: Tragedy of the Commons
subtitle: depletion of a shared resource by individuals acting independently and rationally according to their own self-interest, despite knowing that depleting the resource is contrary to the group's long-term best interest.

title: Collective Action Problem
subtitle: a situation in which multiple individuals would benefit from a certain action, but it has an associated cost, making it unlikely that any one individual will undertake the action.

title: Free-Rider Problem
subtitle: individuals benefit from collective goods without contributing their fair share.

title: Assurance Game
subtitle: a game theory scenario where players want to coordinate but face a risk of defection.

title: Social Capital Phenomenon
subtitle: the collective value of all social networks (who people know) and the inclinations that arise from these networks to do things for each other.

title: Bonding Social Capital
subtitle: social capital derived from strong ties within a homogenous group (e.g., family, close friends).

title: Bridging Social Capital
subtitle: social capital derived from weaker ties between heterogenous groups, connecting different networks.

title: Linking Social Capital
subtitle: social capital derived from ties between individuals or groups and those in positions of authority or power.

title: Social Polarization Phenomenon
subtitle: the division of a population into increasingly extreme or opposing subgroups.

title: Ideological Segregation
subtitle: the separation of individuals into distinct groups based on political or social ideologies.

title: Affective Polarization
subtitle: the tendency to dislike and distrust members of opposing political parties or ideological groups.

title: Echo Chamber Phenomenon
subtitle: reinforcement of beliefs in segregated subgroups through selective exposure to information.

title: Filter Bubble Effect
subtitle: algorithmic personalization leads to selective exposure to information, reinforcing existing views.

title: Opinion Reinforcement
subtitle: the strengthening of existing beliefs due to repeated exposure to similar viewpoints.

title: Social Norm Emergence
subtitle: the process by which shared expectations for behavior arise and become established within a group or society.

title: Convention Formation
subtitle: the process by which arbitrary but mutually beneficial behavioral regularities become established.

title: Taboo Formation
subtitle: the process by which a strong social prohibition against certain actions becomes established.

title: Ritualization (Social)
subtitle: the process by which behaviors become stylized, repetitive, and imbued with symbolic meaning in a social context.

title: Structural Inequality Phenomenon
subtitle: emergent patterns of unequal distribution of resources, power, or opportunities across social groups, embedded in social structures.

title: Income Inequality Phenomenon
subtitle: the unequal distribution of household or individual income across a population.

title: Wealth Inequality Phenomenon
subtitle: the unequal distribution of assets across a population.

title: Social Mobility Barriers
subtitle: obstacles preventing individuals from moving between social strata.

title: Intergroup Relations Phenomenon
subtitle: observable patterns and dynamics arising from interactions between distinct social groups.

title: Prejudice Phenomenon
subtitle: a preconceived negative judgment or opinion about a group or its individual members, often based on stereotypes.

title: Implicit Prejudice
subtitle: unconscious negative attitudes towards a social group.

title: Explicit Prejudice
subtitle: consciously held negative attitudes towards a social group.

title: Discrimination Phenomenon
subtitle: differential treatment, whether intentional or unintentional, against individuals based on their membership in a particular social group.

title: Individual Discrimination
subtitle: discriminatory behavior by one person against another.

title: Institutional Discrimination
subtitle: discrimination embedded in the policies, practices, or laws of organizations or institutions.

title: Stereotyping Phenomenon
subtitle: the application of generalized beliefs to groups, manifesting as a collective social phenomenon.

title: Positive Stereotyping
subtitle: generalized beliefs that attribute favorable traits to a group.

title: Negative Stereotyping
subtitle: generalized beliefs that attribute unfavorable traits to a group.

title: In-Group Favoritism Phenomenon
subtitle: tendency to evaluate one's own group more positively than out-groups.

title: Out-Group Homogeneity Effect Phenomenon
subtitle: tendency to perceive members of an out-group as more similar to each other than they actually are.

title: Intergroup Conflict Phenomenon
subtitle: active disagreement or opposition between social groups.

title: Realistic Group Conflict
subtitle: conflict arising from actual competition for limited resources.

title: Symbolic Group Conflict
subtitle: conflict arising from perceived threats to values or identity.

title: Social Psychological Biases (Collective Manifestation)
subtitle: cognitive biases that manifest or are amplified in social contexts, shaping collective perception and action.

title: Bystander Effect Phenomenon
subtitle: decreased likelihood of intervention in emergencies when others are present.

title: Diffusion of Responsibility (Bystander Effect Factor)
subtitle: a decrease in individual sense of obligation to intervene when others are present.

title: Pluralistic Ignorance (Bystander Effect Factor)
subtitle: individuals' reliance on others' inaction as a cue that no emergency exists.

title: Social Loafing Phenomenon
subtitle: reduction in individual effort when working in a group compared to working alone.

title: Social Proof Phenomenon
subtitle: a psychological and social phenomenon where people assume the actions of others in an attempt to reflect correct behavior for a given situation.

title: Testimonial Influence (Social Proof)
subtitle: use of endorsements by others to persuade.

title: Popularity Bias (Social Proof)
subtitle: tendency to prefer items or behaviors that are widely adopted by others.

title: False Consensus Effect (Collective)
subtitle: the tendency for people to overestimate the extent to which their opinions, beliefs, preferences, values, and habits are normal and typical of those of others.

title: Fundamental Attribution Error (Collective)
subtitle: the tendency for observers to underestimate the impact of situational factors and overestimate the impact of dispositional factors upon the behavior of others, applied to group judgments.

title: Confirmation Bias (Collective)
subtitle: the tendency of groups to search for, interpret, favor, and recall information in a way that confirms their own existing beliefs or hypotheses.

title: Social Change Phenomenon
subtitle: observable patterns of transformation in social structures, norms, values, or behaviors over time.

title: Innovation Diffusion Phenomenon
subtitle: the spread of new ideas/practices through a social system.

title: Adoption Curve (Innovation)
subtitle: the pattern of how an innovation is adopted by different segments of a population over time (e.g., innovators, early adopters, early majority, late majority, laggards).

title: Social Network Influence (Innovation Diffusion)
subtitle: the role of social ties and network structure in facilitating or hindering the spread of innovations.

title: Cultural Evolution Phenomenon
subtitle: the process by which cultural traits, beliefs, and practices change and are transmitted across generations, analogous to biological evolution.

title: Memetic Transmission
subtitle: the spread of ideas or cultural units (memes) from one mind to another.

title: Demographic Change Phenomenon
subtitle: observable patterns of transformation in the composition, size, or distribution of a population.

title: Population Size Change Phenomenon
subtitle: fluctuations in the total number of individuals in a population.

title: Population Growth
subtitle: an increase in the total number of individuals in a population.

title: Population Decline
subtitle: a decrease in the total number of individuals in a population.

title: Population Composition Change Phenomenon
subtitle: shifts in the characteristics or structure of a population.

title: Age Structure Shift
subtitle: changes in the distribution of different age groups within a population (e.g., aging population).

title: Sex Ratio Shift
subtitle: changes in the balance of males and females within a population (e.g., China's One-Child Policy impact).

title: Ethnic Composition Shift
subtitle: changes in the proportion of different ethnic or racial groups within a population.

title: Socioeconomic Composition Shift
subtitle: changes in the distribution of income, wealth, education, or occupation within a population.

title: Population Distribution Change Phenomenon
subtitle: shifts in where a population resides geographically.

title: Urbanization Phenomenon
subtitle: the increasing proportion of a population living in urban areas, leading to changes in social organization.

title: Rural-to-Urban Migration
subtitle: the movement of people from rural areas to urban areas.

title: City Growth
subtitle: the expansion in size and population of urban centers.

title: Suburbanization
subtitle: the growth of populations in areas outside of central cities but within commuting distance.

title: Gentrification
subtitle: the process of renovating and improving a house or district so that it conforms to middle-class taste, often displacing poorer residents.

title: Demographic Transition Phenomenon (Specific Model)
subtitle: the historical shift from high birth rates and high death rates in societies to low birth rates and low death rates.

title: Fertility Decline
subtitle: a decrease in birth rates in a population.

title: Mortality Decline
subtitle: a decrease in death rates in a population.

title: Globalization Phenomenon
subtitle: the increasing interconnectedness and interdependence of world cultures and economies.

title: Economic Globalization
subtitle: the integration of economies through trade, investment, and capital flows.

title: Cultural Globalization
subtitle: the spread of ideas, meanings, and values across national borders.

title: Political Globalization
subtitle: the increasing interconnectedness of political systems and governance structures across the world.

title: Secularization Phenomenon
subtitle: the decline in the influence of religion in a society.

title: Religious Disaffiliation
subtitle: a decrease in formal affiliation with religious organizations.

title: Decline of Religious Authority
subtitle: a decrease in the perceived influence or power of religious institutions in public life.

title: Social Progress Phenomenon
subtitle: an observable, often long-term, improvement in the quality of life or societal conditions.

title: Increased Life Expectancy
subtitle: a rise in the average expected lifespan in a population.

title: Poverty Reduction
subtitle: a decrease in the proportion of a population living below a poverty line.

title: Educational Attainment Increase
subtitle: a rise in the average level of education within a population.

title: Interpersonal Relationship Phenomenon
subtitle: emergent patterns of interaction and dynamics specific to enduring relationships between individuals.

title: Relationship Formation Phenomenon
subtitle: the processes by which new interpersonal relationships are established.

title: Attraction Phenomenon
subtitle: the forces that draw people together into relationships.

title: Disclosure Reciprocity
subtitle: the tendency for individuals to match the level of self-disclosure shared by another person.

title: Proximity Effect (Attraction)
subtitle: the tendency to form relationships with those physically closest to us.

title: Relationship Maintenance Phenomenon
subtitle: the processes and behaviors involved in sustaining interpersonal relationships over time.

title: Trust Building
subtitle: the process of developing confidence in another person's reliability and integrity.

title: Conflict Resolution (Interpersonal)
subtitle: the processes used to manage and resolve disagreements between individuals.

title: Commitment Building
subtitle: the process of strengthening an individual's intention to continue a relationship.

title: Relationship Dissolution Phenomenon
subtitle: the processes by which interpersonal relationships break down or end.

title: Relationship Deterioration
subtitle: the gradual decline in relationship quality.

title: Breakup/Divorce
subtitle: the formal or informal termination of a romantic or marital relationship.

title: Betrayal
subtitle: the violation of trust or loyalty in a relationship leading to its breakdown.

title: Social Exchange Phenomenon (Interpersonal)
subtitle: a theoretical perspective that assumes people are motivated by self-interest and seek to maximize rewards and minimize costs in their relationships.

title: Reciprocity Principle (Interpersonal)
subtitle: the idea that people tend to return favors or positive actions in relationships.

title: Cost-Benefit Analysis (Interpersonal)
subtitle: individuals evaluate relationships or interactions based on perceived rewards versus costs.

title: Attachment Style Phenomenon
subtitle: patterns of relating to others in close relationships that are thought to stem from early childhood experiences.

title: Secure Attachment
subtitle: characterized by comfort with intimacy and autonomy.

title: Anxious-Preoccupied Attachment
subtitle: characterized by a strong desire for intimacy combined with fears of abandonment.

title: Dismissive-Avoidant Attachment
subtitle: characterized by a strong need for independence and discomfort with intimacy.

title: Fearful-Avoidant Attachment
subtitle: characterized by mixed feelings about intimacy, desiring it but fearing rejection.

title: Collective Memory Phenomenon
subtitle: shared recollections and narratives that shape group identity over time.

title: Historical Memory
subtitle: collective recollections of past events that are significant to a group's identity.

title: Cultural Memory
subtitle: shared knowledge, traditions, and narratives passed down through generations within a culture.

title: Public Memory
subtitle: memory constructed and maintained through public discourse, monuments, and commemorations.

title: Traumatic Collective Memory
subtitle: shared memories of a catastrophic event that profoundly impacts a group's identity.

title: Moral Panic Phenomenon
subtitle: rapid, widespread fear or anxiety about a perceived social threat.

title: Folk Devil Creation
subtitle: the process by which a social group is demonized and blamed for societal problems during a moral panic.

title: Media Amplification
subtitle: the role of media in exaggerating or sensationalizing a perceived threat, intensifying a moral panic.

title: Artistic Expression Phenomenon (Collective)
subtitle: the collective creation or reception of art as a social event distinct from individual creativity.

title: Performance Art Phenomenon
subtitle: collective aesthetic experience involving live action, often with audience interaction.

title: Public Art Phenomenon
subtitle: art created for public spaces and consumed by a collective audience.

title: Cultural Festival Phenomenon
subtitle: a collective celebration of art, music, or tradition by a community.

title: Meta
subtitle: The processes, methods, models, and formal languages used for constructing or analyzing entities in other categories

title: Meta-Modeling Technique
subtitle: methods for defining modeling languages and frameworks

title: Abstraction Technique
subtitle: process of simplifying complex reality for modeling.

title: Pattern-Driven Modeling Technique
subtitle: using recurring patterns to guide modeling.

title: Template-Driven Modeling Technique
subtitle: using predefined templates for models.

title: Language-Driven Modeling Technique
subtitle: defining models via specific languages.

title: Knowledge Organization Process
subtitle: procedures for classifying and describing domain concepts

title: Ontology Construction Process
subtitle: building formal representation of knowledge domain.

title: Taxonomy Construction Process
subtitle: creating a hierarchical classification system.

title: Thesaurus Construction Process
subtitle: building a controlled vocabulary with relationships.

title: Terminology Management Process
subtitle: systematic handling of terms and definitions.

title: Metadata Schema Design Process
subtitle: creating structure for descriptive data.

title: Ontology Alignment Process
subtitle: matching concepts between different ontologies.

title: Schema Mapping Process
subtitle: defining correspondences between schemas.

title: Formal Method
subtitle: techniques for precise specification and verification

title: Formal Specification Technique
subtitle: describing system properties precisely using math.

title: Deductive-Proof Technique
subtitle: proving system correctness using logic.

title: Model-Checking Technique
subtitle: algorithmically verifying properties of models.

title: Static-Analysis Technique
subtitle: analyzing code without executing it.

title: SMT-Solving Technique
subtitle: using solvers for satisfiability modulo theories.

title: Abstract-Interpretation Technique
subtitle: analyzing program properties at abstract level.

title: Modeling & Simulation Technique
subtitle: approaches for creating and executing models

title: Mathematical Modeling Technique
subtitle: using mathematical concepts to model systems.

title: Computational Simulation Technique
subtitle: running computer models to imitate systems.

title: Agent-Based Modeling Technique
subtitle: simulating system behavior through agent interactions.

title: System-Dynamics Modeling Technique
subtitle: modeling system feedback loops over time.

title: Representation Language
subtitle: languages for encoding and querying information

title: Data Modeling Language
subtitle: language for defining structure of data.

title: Knowledge Representation Language
subtitle: language for encoding knowledge and inference.

title: Meta-language
subtitle: language used to describe another language.

title: Ontology Language
subtitle: language for defining ontologies.

title: Methodology
subtitle: structured approaches to inquiry, design, and execution

title: Scientific Method
subtitle: systematic process for empirical knowledge acquisition.

title: Engineering Process
subtitle: systematic approach to design and build.

title: Design Process
subtitle: structured approach to creating solutions.

title: Project Management Method
subtitle: managing resources and tasks to achieve goals.

title: Program Management Method
subtitle: managing multiple related projects.

title: Quality Improvement Method
subtitle: systematic approach to enhancing quality.

title: Process Improvement Method
subtitle: analyzing and optimizing workflows.

title: Qualitative Research Method
subtitle: explores non-numerical data for insights.

title: Quantitative Research Method
subtitle: collects and analyzes numerical data.

title: Mixed-Methods Research Method
subtitle: combines qualitative and quantitative approaches.

title: Case Study Method
subtitle: in-depth analysis of a specific instance.

title: Evaluation Technique
subtitle: methods for assessing correctness and performance

title: Verification Technique
subtitle: checking if system meets specification.

title: Validation Technique
subtitle: checking if system meets user needs.

title: Benchmarking Technique
subtitle: comparing performance against a standard.

title: Sensitivity-Analysis Technique
subtitle: assessing output change to input variation.

title: Uncertainty-Analysis Technique
subtitle: quantifying uncertainty in model outputs.

title: Usability Evaluation Technique
subtitle: assessing ease of system use.

title: Risk Assessment Technique
subtitle: identifying and analyzing potential risks.

title: Meta-Research Method
subtitle: methods for synthesizing and evaluating research and models

title: Statistical Meta-Analysis Method
subtitle: statistically combining results from multiple studies.

title: Systematic Review Method
subtitle: comprehensive review of existing research.

title: Evidence Mapping Method
subtitle: mapping available evidence on a topic.

title: Meta-Model Evaluation Method
subtitle: assessing quality and utility of meta-models.

title: Methodological Research Method
subtitle: studying research methods themselves.

title: Bibliometric Analysis Method
subtitle: analyzing research publications quantitatively.

title: Research Impact Assessment Method
subtitle: evaluating the effects of research.

title: Meta-Algorithm
subtitle: algorithmic frameworks that generate, adapt, or optimize other algorithms

title: Meta-Heuristic Algorithm
subtitle: higher-level heuristic for optimization.

title: Hyper-Heuristic Algorithm
subtitle: automates selection/generation of heuristics.

title: Meta-Learning Algorithm (learning-to-learn)
subtitle: improving learning algorithms themselves.

title: Self-Adaptive Algorithm
subtitle: algorithm parameters adjust automatically.

title: Meta-Policy
subtitle: frameworks and models for designing policies, regulations, or governance

title: Policy-Design Framework
subtitle: structured approach to creating policies.

title: Regulatory Meta-Model
subtitle: model for defining regulatory frameworks.

title: Governance Meta-Framework
subtitle: framework for designing governance structures.

title: Technical Standard
subtitle: A formalized specification or framework for systems or processes

title: Internet Standard (RFC)
subtitle: formal specification for Internet protocols/procedures.

title: Industry Standard
subtitle: standard defined by industry consensus.

title: De Jure Standard
subtitle: standard set by law or regulation.

title: De Facto Standard
subtitle: standard adopted through common usage.
